We present the results of a spectroscopic optical survey of radio galaxies in galaxy clusters with redshifts z = 0.4-0.8, which was conducted using the William Herschel Telescope (WHT).
We found that AGN-driven radio galaxies decrease in density within clusters as the galaxy density environment increases.
This is consistent with previous research, which found evidence of the environment's suppressive effect on star formation activities in massive galaxies.
However, we also found many examples indicating that strong radio sources exist in dense regions, without obvious signs that they are being suppressed by the environment.

These celestial bodies may be undergoing rapid evolution, or they may represent a group of recently merged field galaxies, whose properties are still evolving to approach the characteristics of their local counterparts.

The sample includes 20 radio galaxies selected from the VLA-COSMOS 3 GHz large project catalog (Smolčić et al., 2009), with the selection criteria as follows: 1) They are located in one of the four X-ray bright clusters at 0.4 < z < 0.8; 2) Their radio luminosity is above L(3GHz).

We propose utilizing thermal noise in information carriers to achieve completely secure communication, zero-power devices, and computing systems.
We demonstrate that by using appropriate detection schemes, we can extract digital bits from thermal noise with high fidelity at room temperature.
The proposed system is based on single-electron transistors (SET), a technology that has recently been validated in experiments.
In addition, we also demonstrated how to perform logical operations using this single-electron-based device, such as an AND gate and a NOT gate.
Finally, we discussed the potential applications of our proposal, including quantum key distribution, ultra-low power sensor networks, and energy-efficient data centers.
This work was supported by the National Science Foundation under grant number ECCS-0926491.

A new paradigm called "thermal noise informatics" has been introduced, in which thermal noise is used as a carrier of information, applicable to a variety of tasks ranging from completely secure wired communication to zero-power communication and computation.
By employing appropriate detection schemes, research shows that high-fidelity digital bits can be extracted from thermal noise even at room temperature.
It also shows that these extracted numeric bits can be used to perform logical operations, such as AND gates and NOT gates.
The discussion focused on potential applications and their advantages compared to existing technologies.
We proposed a new construction of locally decodable codes (LDCs) based on good subsets of finite fields, the prime factors of Mersenne numbers, and the Chinese Remainder Theorem.
Our first construction is an explicit family of low-density codes (LDCs) with optimal query complexity, which are derived from good subsets of finite fields.

We will then demonstrate how to combine these results with the Chinese Remainder Theorem to obtain a family of LDCs whose parameters can be adjusted by changing the number of primes used in the construction.
Finally, we present a lower bound for any LDC length over a binary alphabet using only single-sided queries.
The proof of our main theorem appears at the end of this extended abstract.

Introduction  
Locally decodable codes (LCDs) are a type of error-correcting code, where each codeword has an associated decoding algorithm that allows for efficient recovery of individual bits or symbols upon querying.
Specifically, if a codeword is corrupted by up to t errors, there exists a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm that can recover the original undamaged word by making O(t) queries per symbol.
This feature makes these codes very useful in applications such as data storage systems, peer-to-peer networks, and streaming distribution services.
A considerable amount of research work is dedicated to understanding the trade-offs between coding rate, code distance, and decoder query complexity.

For example, Guruswami et al. (2005), Chan et al. (2006), and Kopparty and Saraf (2007) studied the problem of constructing encodings with low query complexity while maintaining high rate and long distance.
Recently, several studies have focused on improving known boundaries to determine the minimum query complexity required to decode a single bit given a certain level of damage.

These include the recent breakthrough results achieved by Dvir et al. (2010a), which improved upon the previously known best upper bound proposed by Sudan et al. (2005), as well as subsequent improvements made by Dvir et al. (2011), Feldman et al. (2012), and Kopparty et al. (2013).

We analyzed the relativistic Riemann problem for ideal fluids in two-dimensional space, focusing on the role of vorticity surfaces.

We demonstrate that the solutions to this problem can be constructed through a series of self-similar solutions, which are uniquely determined under translations along the x-axis (the direction of propagation).
The first step is to construct a family that contains exact solutions to describe the interaction between planar shock waves and vortex sheets.
These solutions have been obtained previously by different methods, but here we provide a new derivation based on a feature method.
Specifically, we obtained explicit expressions for the density and pressure distribution at the shock front.
Next, we consider that the initial data consists of a vortex surface that separates regions of constant density and pressure.
This situation physically corresponds to an initially stationary fluid being instantaneously accelerated by a piston at a speed of c = 1.
We prove that for every total mass M, there exists a unique corresponding solution.
Finally, we numerically investigate the evolution of more general initial data composed of multiple vortex surfaces and shock waves.

We report on the detection and characterization of a massive galaxy cluster Abell S1063 (z = 0.90) using data obtained from the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) installed on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).
The star cluster was discovered in a long-distance star cluster survey conducted by our team, with the survey framework being the UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey Data Release 8 (UKIDSS DR8).
We use photometric redshift to select galaxies that may belong to this structure over a wide area around its center.
Using these candidates, we identified two bright brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) that are separated by about 1 arcminute in the line of sight.
The brightness of the BCGs is mF160B = 20.6 ± 0.1 magnitudes and mF140W = 21.0 ± 0.2 magnitudes.
Their colors indicate that they are all early-type galaxies.

We analyzed the linear stability of the self-assembled epitaxial quantum dots (QDs) on the semiconductor surface, which were grown by molecular beam epitaxy under conditions of spontaneous formation and regular arrangement.
We demonstrate that the ordering of quantum dots is determined by two competing mechanisms: surface diffusion and strain relaxation.
The former tends to smooth the quantum dot density distribution, while the latter leads to a steeper distribution.
Specifically, we found that for small values of size dispersion of quantum dots (QDs), there is a critical growth rate above which an ordered array of quantum dots cannot form.
This result explains why it is difficult to grow a large-scale ordered array of quantum dots (QD) using traditional techniques.

Keywords: sorting, strain relaxation, surface diffusion, quantum dot array, stability, growth rate, molecular beam epitaxy

We present an experimental study that explores the complementarity between position and momentum measurements on a single photon, using an improved version of the original Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen photon box experiment.
The results show that for this specific measurement scheme, there is no violation of Bell's inequality or any other forms of non-locality.
We also demonstrated how our experimental setup can be used to study quantum background by conducting two different experiments under the same conditions, but with opposing results.
In one case, we observed that the Bell inequality was violated, while in another case it was not violated.
This indicates that the observed behavior cannot be explained by classical physics and demonstrates quantum contextuality.
Quantum mechanics predicts that certain physical quantities, such as position and momentum, cannot have definite values simultaneously.
These quantities exist only as probability distributions, and these distributions evolve over time according to the Schrödinger equation.

However, research shows that if position and momentum are measured simultaneously, their respective probabilities will undergo coherent interference, resulting in a probability of zero for measuring either quantity at its most probable value. [1]
The phenomenon known as the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle leads to the concept of complementarity: it is impossible to simultaneously observe all properties of a system.

We report the discovery of the X-ray pulsar PSR J1814-1744, which is associated with the unidentified TeV gamma-ray source HESS J1813-178 located at l = 18.6 degrees, b = -0.1 degrees in the Galactic plane.
The rotation period of the pulsar is Psr = 2.16 seconds, located within 0.2 arcminutes (0.01 pc) of the centroid position determined by the High Energy Stereoscopic System (HESS).
We also discovered a faint extended nebula around this pulsar through observations with Chandra.

This nebula exhibits a shell-like structure, with a radius Rneb of approximately 1.5 arcminutes (0.06 pc), which is consistent with what is expected for a pulsar wind nebula driven by relativistic winds.
At radio wavelengths, the observed flux density of the nebula is Fν(3 GHz) ~ 3 millijanskys, while its luminosity in X-rays is Lx ~ 10^33 erg per second.
These values are comparable to those of other young pulsars.

We report the observational results from the High Energy Stereoscopic System (H.E.S.S.) telescope array in Namibia, which detected very high-energy (VHE) gamma rays from the distant quasar 1ES1102-232 (redshift z = 0.186).
The source was observed for more than 50 hours from September 2005 to March 2006 using data collected simultaneously by four telescopes.
In the energy range of 400 GeV to 20 TeV, a total of more than 12 events exceeding the background were observed. No significant changes were observed during this period.

We presented the results of spectral analysis conducted over different time intervals, as well as broadband modeling of multi-wavelength spectra that include measurements ranging from radio to X-rays.
This work demonstrates that H.E.S.S. can detect redshift sources that were previously only accessible through ground-based Cherenkov telescopes.
This also indicates how important these observations are in understanding the physical properties of these extreme objects.

We present the results of the evolution of magnetized protostellar accretion disks, which include Ohmic diffusion and bipolar diffusion, as well as the radiative transfer effects using flux-limited diffusion (FLD).
We found that incorporating these additional physical processes has a significant impact on the structure and evolution of the disk.

Specifically, we indicate that the presence of an initial magnetic field can significantly affect the mass distribution within the early disk, as it suppresses the fragmentation phenomenon near the central star.
This has led to the formation of disks with a greater mass than those previously discovered solely through hydrodynamic simulations.
The disk formed by the results also experienced reduced expansion due to the increased pressure support provided by the magnetic field.
As time goes by, the magnetic field gradually dissipates through ohmic dissipation and turbulence caused by gravitational instability.
Once this happens, the magnetic model's disc will become thinner and more expanded than the non-magnetic model.
We present the research results on the semiclassical scalar propagator in curved spacetime, based on the WKB approximation of the wave function.
We indicate that the quantity can be defined in two different ways depending on whether the feedback effects caused by quantum fluctuations in the gravitational field are taken into account.
The expression for the semiclassical propagator obtained from the first method is consistent with the Feynman propagator at large distances, but shows significant differences near the source point.
Especially, it does not satisfy the Hadamard condition required by general relativity.
On the other hand, if we consider the reaction, then the resulting expression satisfies all necessary conditions, including the Hadamard condition.
However, as recently shown by Wald et al., such an expression cannot be obtained within the framework of standard quantum field theory.

This issue may have significant consequences when considering the propagation of particles through a black hole, as the corresponding expressions exhibit notable differences even outside the event horizon.
We presented high-resolution numerical simulations of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations using the LANS-alpha model, which performs well in wall flows at low Reynolds numbers.
We demonstrate that this method can also be used in high Reynolds number situations, and even though its basic assumptions may no longer be valid, it can still produce accurate results.
Compared to the standard large eddy simulation (LES) method, its main advantage is that it does not require the introduction of an explicit subgrid scale model.
This makes the method非常吸引人 because, unlike other large eddy simulation (LES) methods that require parameter or coefficient adjustments, this method does not require any tuning.

In addition, we demonstrate how to combine the LANS-alpha method with a variational multiscale formulation (VMS-LES) based implicit large eddy simulation (LES) scheme to achieve more efficient computations.
Finally, we discuss some open questions related to the practical application of these solutions.
Turbulence plays a crucial role in many physical phenomena, including weather forecasting, ocean circulation, and combustion processes.
However, despite decades of research, turbulence remains one of the most challenging problems in computational fluid dynamics.
One reason for this difficulty is that the length scales involved in the eddies are very varied.
Due to the fact that large vortices contain most of the kinetic energy, they occupy only a small portion of the total volume.
On the other hand, the smaller vortices almost fill all the space, but their contribution to the overall kinetic energy is minimal.
Therefore, if one wants to accurately resolve all relevant flow structures, it is necessary to use very fine meshes, which will result in extraordinarily high computational costs.
To overcome this problem, what is known as Large Eddy Simulation (LES) has been developed over the past twenty years.

These technologies aim to address only the large-scale movements that account for most of the momentum, while modeling the effects of unresolved small-scale fluctuations using appropriate closure relations.
Although LES has been successfully applied to various engineering problems, it has some drawbacks, such as the lack of universality in the subgrid-scale models used.
In recent years, a new class of methods similar to Large Eddy Simulation (LES) has emerged one after another.

We present new observations and analyses of supernova remnants (SNRs) driving Balmer-dominated shocks into dense molecular clouds, referred to as "molecular cloud shocks" or "Balmer-dominated shocks."
We found that the intermediate temperatures of these shocks are between those of typical J-type shocks and C-type shocks.
The observed emission lines show a significant P-Cygni type spectrum, with blueshifted absorption features indicating velocities of up to 100 km/s.
The results indicate that the transition zone is located at the interface between the shock gas and the unshocked ambient medium.
In addition, we found that the width of the Hα spectral line at the center of SNR W28 gradually increases.
This indicates that the density structure of the surrounding environment may be more complex than previously thought.

Our research indicates that the oscillations of molecular clouds related to the Balmer dominance can provide important information about the physical conditions of the interstellar medium around young supernova remnants.
We provide new U BVRI photometric observations of the barred spiral galaxy NGC 3367 obtained using the 1-meter telescope at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO).
The main objective is to study the stellar structure of the galaxy and its relationship with nuclear activity.
We found that there are two bright nodes along the axis of the galaxy, which may be related to star formation regions.
The color of these knots is similar to the colors found in HII regions.
In addition, we detected several other weak nodules on both sides of the nucleus.
Their color indices indicate that they may be related to recent star formation events.
Finally, we identified a structure extending in a southeast direction, but its nature remains unclear.
This work was supported by CONACyT funding program 36586-E.
We thank J. M. Alloin for his assistance during our observations at CTIO.
Keywords: starburst galaxy; nuclear activity

We study the nonlinear perturbations in general relativity (GR) and other metric theories of gravity, focusing on their effects on conserved quantities (such as the energy-momentum tensor).
We show that these perturbations can be decomposed into two parts: one related to the background geometry and the other related to the perturbation itself.
Specifically, we find that for any given background solution, there are countless solutions corresponding to different values of conserved quantities.
This means that conservation laws are not maintained under small perturbations.
In addition, we demonstrate how this effect leads to a violation of the weak equivalence principle.
Finally, we discussed the possible implications of our results for cosmology and black hole physics.

We report the electronic structure and magnetic properties of zigzag graphene nanoribbons (ZGNR) with different edge structures, including hydrogenated ZGNR (H-ZGNR), fluorinated ZGNR (F-ZGNR), oxidized ZGNR (O-ZGNR), and nitrogen-doped oxidized ZGNR (N-ZGNR).
We found that, except for H-ZGNR being metallic, all of these ZGNRs are half-metallic.
The band gap of F-ZGNR and N-ZGNR increases compared to the original ZGNR, which is due to the difference in electronegativity between the edge carbon atoms and their neighboring atoms.
Conversely, when oxygen replaces one or two carbon atoms at each edge, the band gap slightly decreases because the oxygen transfers charge to the neighboring carbon atoms.
Our results indicate that by introducing oxygen at the edges of zigzag graphene nanoribbons, spin polarization can be enhanced.
We present the analysis results of all available comet dust tail data, including data observed in recent years by spacecraft and ground-based telescopes.
We found that most of these objects are related to Jupiter-family comets (JFCs), which have orbital periods of less than 20 years.
The dust tails produced by JFCs can extend thousands of astronomical units along their orbits.
These tails look like narrow streams of material extending outward from the mother body at high speed.
In certain cases, they show signs of having already split into multiple fragments or branches.
Most of the tail structures we observed are consistent with the models, in which particles continuously release over a timescale ranging from a few months to thousands of years.

However, an increasing amount of observational evidence suggests that these comet tails may also contain a significant amount of newly generated dust particles that have been ejected during recent outburst events.
This indicates that the production rate of dust particles in these systems exhibits significant variation in both space and time.

We proposed an effective model to study the properties of high-density quark matter in the presence of a large quark mass, which is related to compact stars with high central density.
The model is based on the Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) Lagrangian and extends by explicitly introducing vector mesons as degrees of freedom.

We have demonstrated that this extension allows us to simultaneously reproduce several features observed in nuclear physics experiments or theories, such as: i) saturation of nuclear matter; ii) the emergence of resonance in hyperons; iii) the restoration of chiral symmetry at finite baryon density; iv) the existence of a critical endpoint in the phase diagram of strongly interacting matter.
In addition, we found that our results are very consistent with the latest lattice simulation results conducted within the PNJL model framework.
Finally, we discuss how these findings can be used to explore new regions of the NJL model parameter space.
Based on the micro-variability and the star oscillation satellite (MOST) observation data, we present the first results of the differential rotation of an evolved stellar body.
The target is the F-type main-sequence star kappa 1 Cet (HD 128898), which was observed continuously twice between 2005 and 2006.
We found that the surface shear rate decreases towards southern latitudes, but then increases again in the mid-latitudes.
This behavior can be explained by assuming that there are two regions on either side of the equator that rotate at different rates.
In addition to this large-scale pattern, we also detected small-scale features such as spots and light spots.
The lifespan of these structures seems to be between a week and several months.
Finally, we present a comparison of our results with the theoretical predictions made using stellar evolution models.
Keywords: differential rotation; stellar activity; spots; halo; MOST

We report the discovery of three planets around the medium-quality subgiant HD 168625 (with a mass 1.5 times that of the Sun), based on high-precision radial velocity measurements obtained using the HARPS spectrograph at the La Silla Observatory in Chile.
The masses of the planets are 0.7 times that of Jupiter, 2.1 times that of Jupiter, and 3.2 times that of Jupiter, respectively.
We found that the orbital periods of these three planets are all shorter than 100 days; among them, two planets are close to their host star (with orbital periods < 10 days).
These three planets are all located within the habitable zone of their host star.
This is one of the only four known systems to date, in which multiple planets have been found within this region.
These results indicate that it should be possible to detect Earth-like planets in the habitable zones of evolving stars through Doppler spectroscopy.
Keywords: Exoplanets, Planetary Systems

We study the pairing production of double charged scalars with two jets, which can be induced by loops involving heavy fermions (like the top quark) through weak gauge vector bosons (W or Z) and photons.
We derive constraints on the masses of these particles using current experimental data on W+jet and Z+jet processes collected by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).
In addition to the contributions from the standard model background, we also consider the contributions from other new physics models that may have similar characteristics.
The results are presented in the form of constraints on the mass parameters that exclude various new physics scenarios.
Finally, we discuss the signals of this process that may occur in future operations of the LHC.

We present new results on the evolution of dust content in Lyα emitters (LBGs), based on ultra-deep infrared data obtained from the UltraVISTA survey, which is part of the third phase of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.

We studied the impact of radiative transfer (RT) on the 21 cm line UV pumping at high redshift, using cosmological hydrodynamic simulations that include radiative transfer and those that do not.

We found that, compared to calculations that ignore the effects of radio transfer (RT), radio transfer can significantly enhance the intensity of the 21 cm signal, with an amplification of up to one order of magnitude.
The enhancement is mainly due to the Lyman-alpha photons produced within the galaxy, which are absorbed outside the galaxy due to scattering with neutral hydrogen atoms.
This will lead to further heating of the interstellar medium through photoionization heating and Compton cooling.
In addition, we also indicate that the inclusion of RT changes the shape of the power spectrum of the 21 cm brightness temperature fluctuations.
Our results indicate that future radio telescopes, such as SKA, will be able to detect this signal if they have sufficient sensitivity.
Keywords: hydrogen, radiative transfer, power spectrum, cosmic dawn

Introduction  
Research has shown that in dense molecular clouds, interstellar dust particles can grow to millimeter sizes or larger, as they are able to withstand destructive collisions with other particles (for example, the coagulation theory; Ossenkopf and Henning, 1994).

However, recent observations have shown the presence of many small dust particles in dense regions where the gas density exceeds \(10^6 \, \text{cm}^{-3}\) (for example, Stepnik et al., 2003; Pagani et al., 2003), which contradicts this situation.

To resolve this discrepancy, it was proposed that dust particles can be effectively destroyed through collisions when their size is comparable to the mean free path of hydrogen molecules (Ormel et al., 2007).
Another possibility is that the dust particles do not grow during the collision process, but instead break apart into smaller fragments (for example, Blum & Wurm 2008).
If this is the case, then we can expect to see some evidence of particle destruction products in the dense cloud layers, such as submicron-sized fragments.

Indeed, some observational studies have reported the presence of sub-millimeter emission features in dense clouds attributed to silicate and/or carbon-based materials (e.g., Jones et al., 1993; Chiar et al., 1998; Kessler).

We presented the results of simulating the evolution of galaxies in the Millennium Simulation using the semi-analytic code VESPA, including the effects of chemical enrichment and dust attenuation on their observational properties.

We demonstrate that our model can reproduce many observed trends of different types of galaxies at z=0 (for example, the luminosity function), but it also predicts some new trends that can be verified through future surveys such as the Euclid satellite or wide-field survey telescopes.

Especially, we found that: the predicted number density of high-quality static galaxies is too high compared to the observational results; if the feedback efficiency of active galactic nuclei (AGN) is higher than assumed here, this issue may be alleviated.
Our prediction is consistent with the current estimates of the cosmic star formation rate density (SFRD) at redshift 4.5, although beyond this redshift, they tend to slightly overestimate this value.
In low mass (Mstar < 10^10 Msun), there seems to be an excess of blue galaxies compared to red galaxies in both the real universe and our simulation.

This may indicate that our treatment of supernova feedback and/or reionization physics needs improvement, or that these processes are influenced by baryonic effects that are not included in our simulations.
We present here a rigorous mathematical formulation and complete proof of our previous results regarding the equivalence between Ising spin glasses (ISGs) and Ising models (IMs).

We demonstrate that in the thermodynamic limit \( N \rightarrow \infty \) while keeping the ratio \( J / T \) fixed, the ISG partition functions can be mapped to the IM partition functions through an appropriate transformation, which preserves all relevant physical quantities, such as the free energy density \( f = -k_B T \ln Z / N \).

The main idea is to introduce a new set of variables {s} ≡ {s1, ., sN}, which represent the local magnetization of each site i ∈ {1, ., N}, and then map the original problem to a case where spins are coupled only through interactions.
This enables us to rigorously prove that when the number of sites approaches infinity, these two systems have exactly the same statistical properties.

The growth of stellar mass is driven by star formation, which occurs when dense gas collapses to form stars.
The rate at which this process occurs depends on the amount of gas available.
The amount of gas available for collapse depends on the balance between the inflow from larger scales and the outflow from smaller scales.

Star formation occurs when dense gas clouds collapse under their own gravity, resulting in bound objects known as protostars.
These protostars continue to grow by accretion until they reach the main sequence stage, at which point nuclear fusion begins.
During this process, gravitational energy can be released in the form of radiation and kinetic energy, heating the surrounding material and driving powerful winds and jets.
Therefore, to understand the factors that control the rate of star formation, one needs to understand how gas flows into the forming stars.
Gas can flow along filamentary structures towards the formation of stars, either directly or indirectly.
Directly flowing gas may flow along the magnetic field lines, while indirectly flowing gas may be transported by turbulent motion.

Recent observations indicate that direct and indirect flows play important roles in different environments.

We propose a multimodal nested sampling (MNS) algorithm, a novel algorithm that can effectively explore the posterior distribution of high-dimensional parameter space, such as the situations encountered when fitting complex models to observational datasets.
MNS combines the ideas of simulated annealing and importance sampling techniques to find the global maximum likelihood solution within a specified tolerance range.

We demonstrate how to apply this method to practical problems by applying it to two different astrophysical applications: modeling the observed flux of gamma-ray bursts using a time-dependent model; and determining the parameters of binary black hole merger events detected through gravitational waves.

The WiFeS instrument is an integrated field spectrograph on the 2.3-meter telescope at the Australian National University, located at the Siding Spring Observatory in Australia.

The WiFeS instrument consists of two cameras that are mounted on a shared baseplate, which is placed inside a vacuum chamber and connected to the Cassegrain focus of the 2.3-meter telescope at the Australian National University.

Spin echo refers to the phenomenon observed in a spin system after it undergoes two consecutive radiofrequency (RF) pulses with a time interval (referred to as the pulse separation time Tsep) between them.

The first pulse generates a macroscopic magnetization vector \( M_0 \), which precesses around the external magnetic field \( B_{\text{ext}} \) at the Larmor frequency \( f_L = \gamma B_{\text{ext}} \), where \( \gamma \) is the gyromagnetic ratio of the nuclear spin.

After the flip angle θ2 and phase offset φ2 of the second RF pulse relative to the first pulse, the transverse component of the magnetization vector M2(t) experiences exponential decay due to decoherence caused by the local magnetic field generated by nearby nuclei.
In this work, we demonstrate how to generate spin echoes using strong π pulses, even in the absence of an initial net magnetization before applying these pulses.
We have demonstrated both theoretically and experimentally that this spin echo essentially arises from the dipole interactions between nuclear spins.
We present the results of numerical simulations of magnetic rotatorial collapse (MRC) in primordial stars with initial masses between 100 and 1000 M⊙, which formed at redshifts z = 20 to 30.

The final mass of the central object is determined by the strength of the magnetic field.
In a weak magnetic field (B ≈ 10^{10} G), supermassive black holes form.
In addition to its impact on the final quality, the magnetic field also affects the distribution of angular momentum within the collapsing star.
This leads to the generated black holes having different spin parameters, depending on the initial mass of their progenitors.

The lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) is an alternative approach for solving the Navier-Stokes equations in fluid dynamics. Due to its advantages over traditional numerical methods (such as finite difference methods and finite element methods), it has been widely used.
In this work, we proposed a new lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) that can be applied to high-speed compressible flows at high Reynolds numbers by using multiple relaxation times (MRT).
MRT-LBM addresses the discrete velocity model (DVM), where each distribution function represents a component of the macroscopic variables at different velocities on a regular grid.
We use the D2Q9 discrete velocity model to solve the two-dimensional incompressible flow problem.

To validate the algorithm we proposed, several benchmark tests were conducted, including lid-driven cavity flow, Couette flow, Poiseuille flow, Taylor-Green vortex flow, and shock wave propagation in a channel.
Our results show that the numerical solutions obtained by MRT-LBM are in good agreement with previously reported results in the literature.

These features may be related to shock heating caused by merger activities between subgroups or groups.

In this paper, we study the power control problem in Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) cellular mobile radio systems.
We consider an uplink scenario where each user sends signals to their base station using orthogonal spreading sequences, and all users share the same frequency band.
The goal is to minimize the total transmission power while satisfying the individual quality of service constraints for each user's receiver.
In order to obtain manageable results, we utilize tools from stochastic geometry that allow us to model the positions of mobile devices and interference sources as point processes.
Our main contributions are summarized as follows.
First, when the number of active users grows indefinitely, we derive a closed-form expression for the interruption probability.
These expressions can be used to determine the number of users that can communicate reliably over the network simultaneously.
Secondly, we proposed a distributed power control scheme that asymptotically reaches these limits under certain conditions.

Thirdly, we have developed a centralized power control algorithm that can ensure performance close to optimal even when only partial information about channel gain or interference levels is available.
Finally, we present the simulation results of our theoretical findings.
We study the statistical properties of simulated dark matter halos in N-body simulations of cosmology, focusing on their shapes and orientations with respect to each other.
We found that there is a strong correlation between these quantities for halos with a distance less than one half of the super sphere radius (in this region, the density is roughly constant).
This correlation still exists even when we only consider those pairs that are separated by distances greater than their line of sight.
These correlations can be understood as resulting from the tidal forces exerted by the neighboring halo.
In particular, we demonstrate that the distribution of halo shapes is very sensitive to whether they are close to the axis of symmetry of the local gravitational potential field.
Finally, we will compare our results with the observational data of galaxy clusters obtained using weak gravitational lensing techniques.
Our analysis indicates that the observed cluster morphology may provide useful constraints on the nature of the primordial fluctuations that led to the formation of the cosmic structure.
We study whether it is possible to detect anisotropy during the reionization process through the small-scale redshift 21-centimeter power spectrum (21-cm PS) of quasar H II regions.

In our model, we assume that quasars are located at the peaks of dark matter density fluctuations and ionize the surrounding gas with an anisotropic Strömgren sphere, the shape of which is determined by the local tidal field.

Through numerical simulations of different spin temperature \( T_S \) values, we found that the 21 cm power spectrum exhibits a characteristic peak structure, reflecting the shapes of various H II regions.

As the T S decreases, this peak structure becomes more pronounced due to the increase in the number of neutral hydrogen atoms resulting from the reduced brightness temperature difference between the CMB and the 21 cm emission line.
Our results indicate that this peak structure may be utilized to limit the value of T S.
However, since there are many other factors influencing the 21 cm power spectrum besides T S, further research is needed before drawing any conclusions about its detectability.

We studied the dynamics of two types of interacting bosons constrained in an optical lattice, where one type is initially prepared in a coherent state at each position, while the other type is initially prepared as a thermal cloud.
We demonstrate that the system supports both symmetric and asymmetric solitary wave solutions, which are stable against small perturbations at certain chemical potential values.
The stability characteristics of these solitary wave solutions can be understood by studying their linearized spectrum near the equilibrium state.
Specifically, we found that the presence of finite temperature leads to additional unstable modes related to excitations similar to phonons.
Finally, we demonstrate how our results can be used to describe experiments on spinor condensates loaded into optical lattices.

We consider an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel with multiple paths, where each path has different delays and gain coefficients.
We assume that these channels are sparse; that is, only the gain coefficient of a single path exceeds a certain threshold.
The capacity region of this type of channel has already been studied by several authors under different assumptions regarding the number of paths and gains.

In particular, recent studies have shown that if the power of all paths is equal, the capacity region can be achieved by using superposition coding at the transmitter and successive decoding at the receiver.
However, when there is a significant difference in power among the paths, the optimality of this scheme remains unknown.
In this work, we demonstrate that although the optimal scheme may not utilize superposition coding or successive decoding, the performance difference between it and these schemes is not significant.
More specifically, we prove an upper bound on the gap between the rates achievable with any scheme and the total capacity of the channel.

We study the ability of one-way permutation families to withstand certain attacks, where the attackers are computationally limited because they can only make a limited number of queries to the permutation family.
We demonstrate the relationship between this concept and computational complexity theory, and present some new results on the topic.
In particular, we prove that if a one-way permutation family resists non-adaptive chosen ciphertext attacks, then it also resists adaptive chosen ciphertext attacks.
This result implies that for every one-way permutation, there exists another one-way permutation that is simultaneously secure under both types of attacks.

Finally, we introduce a new concept called the distortion measure between two types of one-way permutation families, and use it to derive a lower bound on the security parameters required to withstand different categories of attacks.
The research that led to these results was funded by the European Research Council under the Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013) / ERC grant agreement number 339032.
We present the results of galaxy groups obtained in the largest supercluster SCl 126 (Abell 1689), based on spectral data acquired using the VLT/VIMOS and Keck/DEIMOS telescopes.
We found that galaxies are distributed along filaments connecting different redshift groups.

These findings suggest that there may be significant differences in galaxy properties within a single cluster, depending on their positions relative to other structures.

Introduction: Hot Jupiter is a massive gas giant that orbits a Sun-like star on a short-period orbit.
They represent one of the most extreme environments in our solar system, but they may be widespread around nearby sun-like stars.
In fact, recent surveys show that about 20% of sun-like star systems have such planets.

However, these planets are believed to have formed several astronomical units away and then migrated inward through interactions with the protoplanetary disk and/or gravitational scattering from other bodies.

This raises the question of how these planets avoided being ejected into interstellar space after experiencing strong dynamical interactions with other celestial bodies, while still retaining enough angular momentum to reach their current positions near their parent stars.

In this letter, we report the detection of two new "hot Jupiter" planets identified through high-precision radial velocity measurements obtained over a period of more than eight years using the HARPS (High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher) instrument, which is installed on the European Southern Observatory's 3.6 meter telescope at the La Silla Observatory in Chile.
One of these planets has an extremely small semi-major axis of only 0.04 astronomical units, making it one of the closest exoplanets known to its parent star.

We use three-dimensional numerical simulations of the ideal magnetohydrodynamics equations to study the evolution of magnetized rotating flow under the influence of a strong magnetic field and rotation.

We found that when the initial flow is dominated by toroidal field lines (Btor/Bp = 0.5), it becomes unstable to non-axisymmetric perturbations at t ~ 1.2P0/c, where P0 is the initial pressure scale height.

Instability leads to the formation of spiral structures, which are similar to the structures observed in many astrophysical systems, such as protoplanetary disks or the accretion disks of active galactic nuclei.

Through the addition, we also observed another type of instability that applies to flows initially dominated by polar coordinates (Btor/Bp < 0.1), and this instability develops into an axisymmetric helical structure.
This instability can be understood as a Rossby wave instability caused by the differential rotation between the disk and the corona.
Finally, we demonstrate that the instability of these two types leads to different observational characteristics.

The problem of evaluating propositional logic formulas in conjunctive normal form (CNF) has been extensively studied, and many efficient algorithms have been developed.
However, most existing methods are not suitable for evaluating large CNFs containing millions or even billions of clauses due to their high computational complexity.

In this work, we propose two novel techniques that significantly improve the efficiency of CNF formula solvers: one is based on using GPUs for parallelization, and the other is based on data compression by representing each clause as a bit vector instead of a set of literals.

We have applied these technologies to our new software package CLEVER-CNF, which outperforms the latest solvers, such as SATzilla and Lingeling, on multiple benchmark sets, including those used in the recent SAT competition.
The composition of cosmic rays was studied by measuring their energy spectrum and mass distribution on Earth.
The most accurate measurements are obtained using ground detectors, which measure the extensive air showers produced by the interaction of cosmic rays with atmospheric nuclei.
In this work, we present the results of the shower depth profile measurements, as well as several observable quantities derived from it that are sensitive to the composition.
These include the number of muons per meter water equivalent (N_m), the ratio of muons to electrons at an altitude of 1000 meters (f_1000), and the average logarithmic mass ln(A).
We compared these results under different zenith angles and energy levels.
For primary particles heavier than protons, as the zenith angle increases, \( f_{1000} \) increases while \( N_m \) decreases.

This phenomenon can be explained by the following fact: heavy primary particles interact at high altitudes in the atmosphere, where they produce more muons, but generate fewer electrons compared to lighter primary particles.
At lower energies, there seems to be an excess of events with low values of N_m and high values of f_1000, indicating a possible contribution from light primary particles such as helium or nitrogen.

Spin transistors are important devices for future quantum information processing and communication technologies. However, their practical realization has faced challenges due to a lack of suitable materials with large spin-orbit coupling (SOC).
Here, we propose that graphene can become such a material by leveraging its unique electronic structure.

The proposed device consists of two ferromagnetic contact points, which are connected by a single layer of graphene.
By applying a voltage between these contact points, the spin-orbit coupling strength in the graphene channel can be controlled, leading to a change in its transmission probability.
This originates from a switching behavior similar to that of traditional transistors.
In addition, our analysis shows that the proposed device also exhibits a high switching ratio when operating under practical conditions.
Finally, we discussed the potential experimental implementation of the proposed device.

The relativistic heavy ion collider (RHIC) is an accelerator complex located at Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York.
The main goal of the facility is to study nuclear matter under extreme conditions by colliding heavy ions at high energies and investigating the properties after the collisions.
In addition, it also provides opportunities for other experiments using different particle beams, such as protons or photons.

These measurements were conducted by the Solenoidal Tracker at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) experiment, which uses two large Time Projection Chambers (TPCs) filled with a gas mixture of 90% helium-4 and 10% isobutane-1.
Based on infrared observations from the Spitzer Space Telescope (SST), we have released new results regarding the thermal inertia measurements of near-Earth asteroids (NEAs).

We use these data to derive an improved estimate of the surface thermal inertia, I = 100 ± 50 J m⁻² s⁻¹/² K⁻¹, which is very consistent with previous estimates obtained by other authors using different methods.
The exported values are also consistent with laboratory experiments conducted at high temperatures, which show that thermal conductivity decreases with increasing temperature.
Using the range of thermal inertia we measured, we calculated the expected range of the Yarkovsky force acting on near-Earth asteroids.
Our calculations indicate that this force may be responsible for causing some near-Earth asteroids to enter orbits that intersect with that of Earth.
This will have a significant impact on future space missions aimed at deflecting potentially hazardous objects away from Earth.
Near-Earth Asteroids (NEAs) pose a significant threat to human civilization, as they can collide with the Earth within a million years.
In order to reduce such threats, it is necessary to develop technology that can deflect or redirect near-Earth asteroids (NEAs) from their current orbits before they impact the Earth.
One possible method is to apply small impulses to the asteroid's trajectory through the Yarkovsky-O'Keefe-Radzievskii-Paddack (YORP) effect.
However, the effectiveness of this method largely depends on the ability to accurately predict the intensity of the YORP effect.
We present the results obtained from a novel nuclear fusion method that combines the advantages of microscopic and macroscopic models.

The method is based on an extension of the statistical Hauser-Feshbach theory, taking into account the effects of nuclear structure, including the single-particle level density and transmission coefficients calculated within the Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov (HFB) approximation framework.
We apply this formalism to calculate the cross section of neutron-induced reactions on the nucleus of 132Sn, which is close to the double magic state.
We specifically studied the impact of paired correlations on the fusion process by comparing our results with those obtained using the standard HFB+BCS method.
Our calculations indicate that considering pairing correlations results in significant changes to the predicted fusion probabilities and the corresponding astrophysical S factor.
These differences are particularly notable when considering heavy ion collisions at low incident energies (below the Coulomb barrier).
Keywords: nuclear fusion, statistical model

We report the first simultaneous observations of the candidate black hole GRS 1915+105 in its active state, using both the XMM-Newton telescope and the Spitzer Space Telescope (SST), during which the object exhibited strong variability across all wavelengths.
We found that in the evolution of source brightness in the near-infrared (NIR), optical/ultraviolet, soft/hard X-ray bands, and radio bands, there are two parallel trajectories.
The NIR optical light curve closely follows the hard X-ray light curve but is delayed by about 20 days; while the UV-X-ray trajectory shows no delay compared to the hard X-ray light curve.
This suggests that different physical processes may have led to these two trajectories.
Through supplementation, we also found evidence of lagged effects present in the two tracks.
These results provide new insights into the accretion flow physics of supermassive black holes.
The variable star single imaging project is an open-source software package for astronomical data analysis.
It was developed by members of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in collaboration with researchers from institutions around the world.

The goal of this project is to provide a single tool that can analyze all types of astronomical datasets, including photometric time series, spectral observations, images, etc., using state-of-the-art techniques such as image subtraction, cross-correlation, period-finding algorithms, spectral line fitting, and more.
The software is released under the GNU General Public License version 3.0 and is available on GitHub at the following link: https://github.com/VariableStar/one-shot-astro.
"The one-time astronomical tool includes multiple instruments that can quickly and efficiently analyze a large amount of astronomical data."

These include the one-shot data cleaner, which is used for automatic quality control checks on raw data files; the one-shot mosaic, which is used to create multiple jittered exposure mosaic images; the one-shot astrometry, which is used to determine astronomical measurements for a single frame or the entire mosaic image; the one-shot photometry, which is used to measure the flux and/or brightness of celestial objects in the field; the one-shot pipeline, which integrates these different tasks into a single automated pipeline; and the one-shot Wikimapia, which allows users to create custom sky maps based on their own celestial catalogs.

In addition to these core packages, there are many additional modules available through the one-shot-astro repository. These modules allow users to perform more specialized analyses, such as: one-shot-catalog, which provides access to various astrophysical databases through SQL queries; and one-shot-fastphot, which uses machine learning methods to measure stars.
We proposed an algorithm for obtaining spatio-temporal metrics from observational data, such as data obtained from the Planck satellite and other experiments.
The method is based on the equivalence between Einstein's field equations in general relativity (GR) and the geodesic equations of test particles.
We use this equation to directly obtain the metric tensor components of the observation trajectories of photons emitted at different redshifts.
This method allows us to reconstruct the complete four-dimensional geometry in spacetime without assuming any specific model or parameterization.
To demonstrate our technology, we applied it to simulated data generated using publicly available code CAMB.
Our results indicate that the recovery metrics are very consistent with the original metrics used to generate the simulated data.
Finally, we discuss the potential application of our method to actual astrophysical datasets.

We present the results of the distribution and luminosity function (LF) of active galactic nuclei (AGN) in galaxy clusters based on Chandra observations of 16 galaxy clusters with redshift in the range of 0.1 < z < 1.0.
We found that the proportion of X-ray luminous active galactic nuclei (AGNs) increases with redshift but decreases with the increase in cluster mass.

The luminosity function (LF) of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) can be well described by a power law with an exponential cutoff above \( L_x = 10^{43} \, \text{erg} \, \text{s}^{-1} \, \text{Hz}^{-1} \).
The best-fit parameters are consistent with the results of field AGNs within their uncertainty range.
These results indicate that active galactic nuclei play an important role in heating the gas within clusters and regulating star formation activity in the clusters.

Based on this work, we propose an efficient direct voting scheme to provide Data Fusion Assurance (DFA) in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs).

The proposed DFA scheme is based on the concept that each node can directly vote on its local decisions in conjunction with the decisions of other nodes, and then obtain the final global decision through a majority voting rule.

To reduce the communication overhead caused during the direct voting process, our方案采用了两种新颖的技术: 1) Only one-hop neighbors can vote at any given time; 2) All nodes transmit their votes simultaneously using different time slots.
We also presented a theoretical analysis to demonstrate how much energy consumption would be saved compared to existing solutions.
Finally, extensive simulation results show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and power efficiency.
Keywords: Data fusion assurance, wireless sensor networks, energy-saving direct voting scheme.

The missing satellite problem (MSP) is one of the most important issues in space science and technology, with applications ranging from satellite navigation to space debris removal.
The MSP inquires about all orbits that are stable under gravitational perturbations from known celestial bodies (such as planets or asteroids).

In this study, we propose an algorithm that can exactly solve the Minimum Path Problem (MSP) in any dimension d >= 2, with a required time of O(n log n + m log n), where n = |S| is the total number of objects in the set S, and m = |E| is the number of edges. Our method combines several novel techniques, including fast matrix multiplication algorithms, data structures based on interval trees, and efficient graph traversal methods.
We also demonstrated how our results can be used to address relevant problems, such as finding the minimum distance between two given point sets in R^d.
Finally, we demonstrate the practicality of our method through experiments conducted on real-world datasets.
We reported the polarization-dependent photoluminescence (PL) and Raman scattering spectra of CdSe/CdS core-shell quantum dots in solution at room temperature.

The PL spectrum shows that the emission is polarized in a direction perpendicular to the excitation light, which can be explained by the selection rules for dipole transitions between electronic states of different angular momentum.
In addition, we observed the anisotropic broadening of the Stokes line width, as well as the splitting into two components when exciting with circularly polarized light.
These effects are attributed to the presence of exciton fine structure caused by spin-orbit coupling.
We also found evidence of strong electron-phonon interactions, which led to phonon sidebands in the Stokes and anti-Stokes parts of the Raman spectrum.
Finally, we demonstrated how to use these results to determine the orientation of individual quantum dots embedded in a polymer matrix.
Polarized luminescence measurements were performed on individual quantum dot emitters using a confocal microscope.

We reported deep near-infrared observations using VLT/VISIR, which show that the X-ray source NGC 300 X-1 is associated with an infrared point source (the X-ray counterpart) located at right ascension 03h 45m 55.6s and declination -27° 19' 59.9'' (J2000), situated in the central part of the Galactic spiral arm.
The observed flux is consistent with that of the expected WR star, which has an effective temperature of about 50 kK and a surface gravity of approximately 5.5-6.0.
We also found extended emission evidence around this source, which may be caused by dust heated by stellar winds or radiation fields.
Using our VISIR data, we estimate the total number of WR stars in NGC 300 to be NWR = 1.1 x 10^7 ± 0.3 x 10^7 per M_sun.
This value is consistent with previous estimates based on HST/ACS imaging and spectroscopy.
Keywords: Wolf-Rayet star
We proposed a new model of non-Abelian string networks, which is based on the idea that the network consists of many intertwined strings with different speeds and directions.
We demonstrated how to construct such velocity-dependent models using Feynman diagrams.

We specifically consider two types of diagrams: (i) ladder diagrams, corresponding to the exchange of gluons between a pair of strings, and (ii) crossed ladder diagrams, describing interactions among three or more strings.
The latter type of diagram can be interpreted as representing the intersection where several strings meet at a point.
We discussed some properties of these models and compared them with previous results obtained within the framework of the Abelian-Higgs model.
Finally, we investigate the process of evolution from an initial configuration containing a single straight string into a complex interaction of string entanglements through Monte Carlo simulations.
This work was supported by the German Research Foundation (DFG) under contract SFB-TR9 "Gravitational Physics."

We present the results of a study that investigates the properties and evolution of transients that occur when using Lagrangian Perturbation Theory (LPT) to generate initial conditions in cosmological N-body simulations.

We found that initial conditions based on LPT lead to false large-scale power in the late stages, and increasing the number of particles used to generate these initial conditions does not suppress this phenomenon.
This effect can be mitigated by applying a low-pass filter to the evolved density field before generating new initial conditions using high-order LPT.
However, this method does not completely eliminate all the negative effects associated with using LPT to generate initial conditions.
In addition, we demonstrate how the choice of time step for evolving initial conditions affects its accuracy.
Finally, we demonstrate that accurate initial conditions for large-scale cosmological simulations can be constructed without relying on expensive high-resolution hydrodynamic simulations.
"Generate realistic initial conditions for cosmological N-body simulations."
The work function is one of the most important parameters in semiconductor devices, and its accurate measurement is crucial for device design and performance prediction.

In this article, we review some recent advances in determining the work function of various materials using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) with synchrotron radiation, as well as other techniques such as scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS), inverse photoelectron spectroscopy (IPES), and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM).
We also discussed how to determine the absolute value of the work function of different semiconductors based on UPS measurements.

The study of evolutionary game theory examines how strategies evolve over time when players repeatedly interact in large populations.
It provides a natural framework for analyzing the strategic interactions among self-interested agents who cannot commit in advance but have the opportunity to learn by observing past games.
A typical example of this situation occurs in bargaining scenarios, where each agent takes turns making offers without knowing what proposals the opponent will put forward.
This issue was first studied by Guth et al. (1982), who introduced the so-called ultimatum game as a model for bargaining between two self-interested individuals.
In this game, Player 1 proposes to divide a fixed amount M into x and y = M − x, giving x to themselves and y to Player 2; Player 2 can either accept or reject this offer.
If he accepts, the two players will receive their respective shares according to the proposal; otherwise, they will gain nothing.

Since the pioneering work of Guth and others, many authors have studied various aspects of the ultimatum game, including the existence and multiplicity of equilibria, as well as the efficiency losses resulting from a lack of commitment ability.

We study the evolutionary dynamics within a set of genotypes, where each genotype has its own fitness value and is interconnected with other genotypes through mutations.
We demonstrate that for large populations, there is always a genotype that has more connections than any other genotype.
This genotype is advantageous over all other genotypes in a balanced state.
The advantage of this genotype only depends on the distribution of mutation distances between genotypes.
For example, if we consider two different mutation distance distributions (exponential distribution and power law distribution), the same genotype will prevail in both cases.
However, the time required to reach equilibrium can vary significantly depending on the number of pathways leading to the advantageous genotype.

Specifically, when the number of paths originating from the dominant genotype increases exponentially with distance, the system reaches equilibrium more quickly than in cases where the number of paths increases more slowly or even remains constant.
We also found that the average population size of the dominant genotype slowly decreases over time until it reaches equilibrium.

The vapor pressure, water solubility, and interfacial tension between oil and water are important parameters for understanding the behavior of crude oil during production or transportation through pipelines.
In this study, we used an alcohol monolayer in an aqueous phase as a model system to simulate the hydrocarbon chains present in crude oil and investigated these characteristics.
The results indicate that the vapor pressure of alcohols increases with the chain length up to C8, but then decreases above C10.

This can be explained by considering the competition between two opposing effects: on one hand, the increase in chain length leads to an increase in molecular volume, which is favorable for evaporation.
On the other hand, longer chains can lead to stronger van der Waals interactions in the liquid phase, resulting in lower vapor pressure.
We found that the solubility of alcohols is similar to the observed trend in vapor pressure.
However, compared to the corresponding differences in vapor pressure, the differences in solubility between different chain lengths become smaller.
Finally, our measurement results show that the interfacial tension between the alcohol layer and the water below decreases monotonically with the increase of chain length.

Glutamatergic synapses are the most abundant excitatory connections in the brain, but how they are formed is not well understood.

Here, we demonstrate that glutamate receptors (GluRs) can be directly transported to synaptic sites through lateral diffusion on the cell membrane, or indirectly transported to synaptic sites through endocytosis followed by recycling from endosomes.

We used total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy for single particle tracking to observe the dynamics of GluR2-containing AMPA receptors labeled with quantum dots on the dendrites of hippocampal neurons.
The results revealed two distinct receptor transport pathways for delivering receptors to the synapse.
First, the receptors laterally diffuse on the surface until they encounter an existing synapse, where they are captured.

Secondly, the receptor enters the endosomal vesicle after endocytosis, then it is recycled to the cell surface through Rab11-positive recycling endosomes, and is subsequently directed to a new synapse.
These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of functional neural circuit formation during development and the plasticity of mature neurons.
We present the results of the unique Type Ia supernova (SN) 2005bf in NGC 6946, which is one of only two supernovae with a clear association with gamma-ray bursts (GRBs).
The light curve and spectral evolution were compared with other supernovae related to gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) as well as normal Type Ia and Type IIb supernovae.
We found that SN 2005bf exhibits several unusual features among these objects.
In particular, its decay rate during the nebula phase is very slow, indicating that its ejected mass may be much greater than the expectations for ordinary core-collapse supernovae.
This indicates that the mass of the progenitor star is sufficiently large to directly form a black hole without going through the neutron star phase.

If this is the case, we expect that the central engine of the relevant gamma-ray bursts will gain energy from matter falling into such black holes, rather than being driven by radioactive decay energy.

Our analysis also indicates that the explosion site should be located near the center of the host galaxy, suggesting that the progenitor system may have experienced significant birth shocks before the explosion.

We studied how classical and quantum uncertainties affect the changes in price dynamics in environments with incomplete information, where agents can access different sources of information about the underlying state variables.

We indicate that when traders do not have common knowledge about the true value of state variables, even if everyone is rational and risk-neutral, they may still have disagreements about the future expected evolution.
This divergence leads to price fluctuations, which are exacerbated by the presence of noisy traders who trade solely based on their private signals.
In this context, we find that stock returns exhibit volatility clustering and fat tail phenomena, similar to what has been observed empirically.
Finally, we demonstrate that these effects persist for both classical states and quantum states with non-Gaussian statistics.
The results presented here provide new insights into the role that uncertainty plays in affecting the statistical properties of asset returns.
They also suggested possible avenues for further research, aiming to understand the origins of such phenomena within more realistic models of trading behavior.

We proposed an algorithm based on the Weighted Essentially Non-Oscillatory (WENO) method for numerically solving the time-dependent equations that describe the growth of ionization regions in the early universe.

The numerical solution is obtained by simultaneously solving two coupled partial differential equations, which describe the evolution of the ionization fraction and temperature field within each cell of the grid covering the computational domain.
We demonstrated how to use this method to study the reionization process driven by ultraviolet photons emitted from galaxies.
In particular, we compare our results with those obtained using smoothed particle hydrodynamics techniques.

Our tests indicate that both methods produce qualitatively similar results, but there are some quantitative differences between them that may have significant implications for studying the statistical properties of the IGM during the reionization period.

We re-examine the slow relaxation process of a model glass-forming system, specifically a binary mixture of Lennard-Jones particles interacting through the Weeks-Chandler-Andersen potential, which has an additional repulsive shoulder at short distances.

We analyzed the data obtained from the Chandra X-ray Observatory to search for evidence of dark matter particles being annihilated through collisions at the center of the Milky Way (GC).

We proposed an analytical model to study the effects of mass loading feedback on particle concentration and vortex strength in fully developed turbulence.
The cascading process is modeled by a set of coupled ordinary differential equations, which are derived based on dimensional analysis and the Kolmogorov similarity hypothesis.
We indicate that the presence of particles can significantly affect the energy transfer rates between different scales and the dissipation rates at small scales.

Our research findings provide useful insights into understanding how heavy particles affect the dynamics of fluid flow.

The V404 Cygni X-1 is an X-ray binary system that contains a neutron star and its companion star, and has been observed across multiple wavelengths from radio waves to gamma rays.

The source shows periodic waning activity in the X-ray energy range, which is caused by matter falling into the accretion disk around the compact object, thereby obscuring the central X-ray emission region.

In this work, we present results obtained using data collected from two different observational activities, which were conducted with the Suzaku satellite (from 2005 to 2007) and the INTEGRAL/IBIS telescope (from 2003 to 2009).

We conducted new observations of three protostellar cores in the Orion B region, which are among the youngest known protostellar objects.
These data were obtained through the Submillimeter Array (SMA) at wavelengths of 1.3 mm and 0.87 mm, as part of an ongoing survey aimed at studying the earliest stages of star formation.
We have found that all three sources indicate evidence of falling motion on a scale of 1000 AU to 10000 AU.
By adding, we have detected outflows related to these two sources.
These results indicate that the first stage of star formation is characterized by the rapid accumulation of mass towards the central body through a surrounding protoplanetary disk.
This process may be triggered by gravitational collapse within the core or magnetic rot instability.
Finally, our SMA images show extended emission around each source, which may represent a flattened envelope or disk surrounding the central star.
Our research results provide important constraints for theoretical models describing the early evolution of young stellar objects.
The structure and dynamics of lipid membranes are critical for many biological processes, such as cell division or protein transmembrane transport.
In this work, we used atomic force microscopy to study the structural characteristics of stacked phospholipid layers in water.
We found that these structures spontaneously form on the surface of mica at room temperature, just a few minutes after adding the lipids to the solution.
The height profile shows that the thickness of a single layer varies between 1 nanometer and 2 nanometers depending on its composition.
By analyzing the relationship between the lateral diffusion coefficient of individual molecules and time, we can determine whether they are mobile or fixed.
Our results indicate that charge mobility strongly depends on the number of layers in each stack.
For example, although most molecules in one layer can freely diffuse over larger distances, molecules in two layers only exhibit slight displacements that are perpendicular to the surface.
This behavior indicates that when more than one layer is formed, liquidity significantly decreases.

We studied the ground state properties of a spin-1/2 square lattice with nearest-neighbor antiferromagnetic interactions and vacancies, using exact diagonalization (ED) methods on finite clusters with up to 12x12 sites.

We found that, under low concentration of defects, there is no significant change in the energy gap between the magnetic ordering parameters or between the singlet and triplet excitations compared to the pure system.
However, when the concentration of vacancies increases, we observe an increase in the density of states at the zero energy level.
This effect can be explained by considering the formation of localized pairs of bound vacancies due to interactions.
The strength of the interaction between these pairs strongly depends on the distance between them, but only weakly depends on the size of the cluster being considered.
In addition, we demonstrate how this behavior changes if we consider next-nearest neighbor interactions instead of nearest neighbor interactions.
Finally, we discussed the possible experimental implementation of our results.
We present the results of an investigation into the continuous emissions from the accretion disks of black hole candidates (BHCs).

We have developed an analysis model to calculate the spectra emitted by thin, optically thick accretion disks around Schwarzschild black holes, and we have applied it to several black hole candidates with known mass functions.
When we assume that the inner edge of the disk is located at 6 gravitational radii, the observed spectrum is well reproduced.
This result indicates that the standard thin disk model can serve as a good approximation for modeling the X-ray continua of these celestial bodies.

Keywords: Black hole -- Spectroscopy -- X-ray -- Modeling -- Accretion disk -- Emission line -- Broadband spectral energy distribution -- Luminosity function -- Mass measurement -- Stellar-mass black hole -- Supermassive black hole -- Active galactic nucleus -- Quasar -- Cosmic evolution

1 Introduction

In recent years, significant progress has been made in understanding the physical processes occurring near supermassive black holes (SMBH) in active galactic nuclei (AGN), quasars, and other similar systems.
These studies rely on observations of the broadband spectral energy distribution (SED) of supermassive black holes in frequency space over multiple decades.
However, due to their great distances, direct measurements of the luminosity of the interiors of most active galactic nuclei (AGN) are not possible.

On the contrary, people can use indirect methods, such as reverberation mapping or statistical correlations among various properties of different active galactic nuclei (AGNs), to determine their luminosity.
For example, if the amount of light passing through a region of interest within an active galactic nucleus (AGN) is known, simple geometric reasoning can be used to calculate its luminosity.
Additionally, if the distance to an active galactic nucleus (AGN) is known, its absolute magnitude can be measured directly.
Unfortunately, both methods require a detailed understanding of the structure of the launching area, and currently, this information cannot be obtained through observation.

Therefore, to accurately estimate the luminosity of distant active galactic nuclei, it is necessary to develop models that can reproduce the spectral energy distribution (SED) observed in nearby active galactic nuclei.

We propose an improved metric suitable for the space of world-sheet σ models with coupling, which is appropriate for studying gradient renormalization group flows that go beyond first-order perturbation theory.
The new indicators have several advantages compared to previous proposals, including a significant positive momentum term and not requiring additional counter-terms at higher orders.
We demonstrate how to use this measure to calculate the β function up to third order in perturbation theory, using only Feynman diagrams with single-loop vacuum bubbles as building blocks.

This enables us to obtain results regarding the beta function related to the coupling of the tweaking field and the Riemann scalar that are consistent with those obtained by other methods, but these results were previously unavailable due to technical difficulties.
In addition, we found evidence of non-trivial fixed points in the beta function of the string coupling constant.
These results further support the idea that the worldsheet σ model may be a useful tool for studying quantum gravity.
Introduction: Recent studies have shown that the Worldsheet σ Model (WSSM) provides a powerful framework for exploring quantum gravity through its connections with gravitational path integrals.

One particularly interesting aspect of this method is its ability to directly calculate the perturbative corrections to the WSSM action from the gravitational path integral, without relying on explicit calculations involving gravitons or graviton loops [3].
It is mentioned in [4] that WSSM can also be used to study the flow of effective action under renormalization group (RG).
However, since the WSSM contains an infinite number of degrees of freedom, there is no finite-dimensional parameter space in which RG flow can occur.
On the contrary, RG flow must proceed along some infinite-dimensional trajectory in all possible action spaces.
In order to make progress in understanding such trajectories, it would be helpful to define a reasonable metric in the space of the WSSM's effects to measure the distances between different effects.
This measure should be able to determine whether two given behaviors are close or distant in all possible WSSM spaces.
We introduce the concept of dynamic objects related to cohomological extension maps and prove that in many cases they are equivalent to the usual objects.

We consider the problem of energy-efficient modulation for downlink transmission in Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) networks, where each user has individual delay constraints and is equipped with a rechargeable battery that can be charged by harvesting ambient radio frequency signals.

We present mid-infrared (MIR) spectra obtained with Spitzer/IRS at high spatial resolution from the central region of the Virgo Cluster.

The mid-infrared (MIR) emission is primarily dominated by features associated with polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and silicate absorption bands, which extend spatially along the sub-axis of the galaxy over kiloparsec (kpc) scales.
