These results indicate that even when active galactic nuclei are located in crowded regions such as the center of rich clusters like Virgo, their infrared (MIR) characteristics can still be studied.

Image registration is an important problem in medical imaging and computer vision, with the goal of finding a transformation that aligns two or more images taken at different times and/or by different sensors.
In this work, we propose an evolutionary optimization method for the template-based image registration problem.
We consider performing rigid and non-rigid transformations on the image.
The proposed algorithm was tested on synthetic data as well as on a real dataset that includes brain MRI scans and CT angiography (CTA) volumes.
Our results show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in terms of accuracy while also being computationally efficient.
This research was funded by EPSRC, grant number EP/N014560/1.

We study the dynamics of one-dimensional open quantum systems, focusing on their ability to generate entanglement at large distances, as well as how these abilities are impacted by decoherence.

We consider two different models of the interaction between the system and the environment: (i) local coupling between the environment and each position; (ii) global coupling between the environment and all positions simultaneously.
In both of these cases, we find that there are mechanisms that allow the system to be driven into a highly entangled state, even when it starts from an unentangled or only weakly entangled state.
This occurs because the environment acts as a noise source, driving the system to evolve towards its ground state.
The impact of local coupling is more pronounced than that of global coupling, as the former allows for faster relaxation time scales.
Finally, we indicate that these results also hold true when there is a certain degree of spatial correlation in the initial state.
Quantum information processing requires manipulating quantum states over long distances.
However, due to the inevitable interactions with the surrounding environment, these operations cannot be perfectly executed.
Here, we study whether certain types of environments actually enhance the performance of quantum devices.

We analyzed the stability of planetary systems, in which protoplanetary embryos evolve under oligarchic rule, meaning that they can gravitationally scatter and repel their neighboring bodies, but cannot repel themselves.
We found that this process leads to rapid growth of the maximum embryo until it reaches its isolated mass (the minimum mass required for escape from aggregation).
The system then evolves into either a single planet or two planets of comparable mass, depending on how close the initial conditions are to instability.

This evolution is very different from the situation where all objects grow simultaneously; in particular, we demonstrate that even if the initial conditions are the same, multiple stable outcomes may arise.
Our results indicate that the formation of terrestrial planets may have gone through several stages, including a oligarchic stage, before achieving the final state we observe today.
In addition, our research provides new insights into the origin of super-Earths.
The original planetary embryos form in the protoplanetary disks around young stars and experience mutual gravitational interactions during their growth phase.
These interactions lead to orbital migration and dynamic instability, such as collisions between neighboring embryos.
Because these processes occur frequently enough, ultimately only one celestial body will survive at the end of the growth phase, resulting in a planetary system composed of just one planet.
However, recent studies have shown that many planetary systems contain more than one planet, indicating that some mechanism must be in place to prevent the complete destruction of the system.

Here, we study whether protoplanetary embryos follow a layered evolutionary path, in which they first grow hierarchically through gravitational scattering and then begin to rapidly accumulate after the largest embryos reach their isolation mass.
Through numerical simulations, we demonstrate that this scenario naturally explains the existence of multi-planet systems, while also reproducing the characteristics of known exoplanets.
We use hydrodynamic simulations to study how protoclusters grow and evolve from galaxy clusters, focusing on baryonic components at high redshifts (z > 5).
We found that most of these regions are highly ionized at z = 3 due to photoheating from the ultraviolet background radiation.
The resulting low neutral hydrogen fraction leads to a lower density of absorbers along the line of sight towards these celestial bodies, compared to observations at lower redshifts.
This effect is more pronounced in larger halos, as their gas fractions are greater than those of smaller halos.
Using this result, we derive the constraints on the abundance of high-redshift protoclusters with respect to halo mass.
These results can be used to test models of structural formation and reionization.
In addition, they provide useful input parameters for future studies of cluster scale relations using weak lensing techniques.

Introduction  
In recent years, there has been increasing attention on understanding how gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) produce their broad-band electromagnetic radiation.

This effort has resulted in several successful models to describe the transient phase of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) (see, for example, Piran 2005; Zhang 2007), but there has been less progress in explaining the origin of the afterglow component.
A key feature of most afterglows is the steep or "jet break" that appears in the light curve about a day after the explosion (Rhoads 1999).
Such interruptions are typically interpreted as marking the moment when the relativistic jet becomes optically thin to synchrotron self-absorption, leading to a rapid decrease in flux density.

However, some authors believe that this intermittency may also occur during the process of continued energy input to the ejecta after the initial explosion (for example, Kumar & Panaitescu 2000; Granot et al. 2001; Chevalier & Li 2000), while others suggest that it may be due to changes in the geometry of the emission region (for example, Racusin et al. 2008).

We have measured the mass function of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) for the first time, including early-type (elliptical/S0, Sa-Sb) and late-type (Scd-Sm) galaxies, using data from the Millennium Galaxy Catalog (MGC).
We use two different methods to measure the mass of supermassive black holes - stellar velocity dispersion measurements and the relationship of luminosity calibration in globular clusters.
Our results indicate that there is no significant difference between the mass distribution functions of supermassive black holes (SMBH) for these galaxy types when z < 0.1.
However, we found evidence suggesting that, as redshift evolves, the number density of powerful supermassive black holes decreases more rapidly than that of smaller black holes.
This indicates that the heaviest supermassive black holes may have grown through accretion over cosmic time rather than through merger events.

The average logarithmic magnitude dispersion of all the samples considered here is 0.3 astronomical units (in a factor of 2).

This result indicates that there are two groups of dust-rich star formation regions present in each galaxy—one associated with normal star formation activity and the other associated with intense star formation bursts.
Our research also indicates that the proportion of galaxies containing such extreme objects increases at higher redshifts.
These findings are significant for understanding the physical processes of distant galaxy evolution and their contribution to the cosmic infrared background radiation.
Keywords: infrared, galaxy
We present the Hamiltonian formulation of general relativity with matter fields, applicable to arbitrary spacetime manifolds, encompassing both classical and quantum aspects.
The basic idea is to use ADM decomposition to separate the metrics into spatial and temporal components, as well as time intervals and displacement functions.
We then introduce the canonical momenta conjugate to these variables, which are used to construct the fundamental constraints of the theory.
These constraints lead to symmetry transformations, under which all physical quantities remain invariant.
To obtain the correct degrees of freedom, we must impose secondary constraints to eliminate non-physical modes.
Finally, we perform canonical quantization, elevating the phase space variables to operators that act on the wave function in superspace (the space of all possible metrics).
This leads us to the Wheeler-DeWitt equation, whose solutions can be interpreted as the amplitudes of probability between different states of the universe.
We also discussed how this method applies to inflation models.

We present the results of long-term numerical simulations of binary black hole (BBH) evolution, which include gravitational wave reaction as well as general relativistic effects such as frame dragging and tidal disruption.
We focus on binary star systems with a total mass of M = 100-1000M⊙, which evolve in the collision environments of high redshift z > 10.
Our main goal is to study how binary black holes grow through accretion in dense gas clouds during the early stages of their evolution.
In particular, we study whether these systems can merge after reaching a mass exceeding 1000 M⊙ within the Hubble time.
The initial conditions of our model are obtained through Monte Carlo sampling of the distribution function of isolated black hole binaries (BBH) constructed by Belczynski et al. (2010).
For each model, we conducted several experiments starting from different track configurations.
All calculations are assumed to be conducted in a circular orbit.
We found that most massive binary stars merge within a few hundred million years after formation due to the emission of gravitational waves.

These results improve upon the previous experimental limits by more than an order of magnitude.

BiFeO3 is an antiferromagnetic insulator with a high Curie temperature (TC = 1103 K) and exhibits ferroelectricity at room temperature when doped or subjected to pressure.

Here, we report the observation of spontaneous magnetization M(T) and polarization P(E) coexisting in pure BiFeO3 single crystals grown by the solvent method over a wide temperature range up to 300 K.
The results show that below the critical temperature (TC), M(T) and P(E) are almost independent of each other, but above TC, they begin to decrease rapidly.
We also found that the rate of decrease in the size of M(T) is faster than that of P(E).
These observations indicate a strong coupling between the spin and lattice degrees of freedom in the material.

We presented the results of our study on the physical properties of weak Mg II absorbers (WAs) in quasar spectra, utilizing high-resolution spectroscopy and photoionization models.

We found that WAs are typically associated with galaxies that have a stellar mass M* of about 10^10 to 10^11 solar masses, a star formation rate (SFR) of 0.1-10 solar masses per year, and a metallicity Z of 0.2 - 1 times the solar metallicity.
Most of the systems have lower ionization parameters log U < -2.5, indicating that they are likely primarily dominated by diffuse gas rather than dense clouds.

We proposed an algorithm based on Voronoi tessellation (VT) technique for finding galaxy clusters using photometric redshift.

In this work, we consider a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) system in which each transmitter provides limited feedback information about its channel state to the receiver.
We assume that there is no cooperation between transmitters in terms of power distribution or transmission strategies.
Each transmitter can only adjust its own transmission power level based on the local CSI knowledge at the transmission end.
In addition, each transmitter must completely turn off its radio when there is no data to send.
The goal is to maximize the total rate by simultaneously optimizing the power control strategies and transmission strategies of all users under these constraints.
First, we derive the achievable rates and upper bounds under the assumption of using Gaussian codebooks, utilizing finite-rate feedback.
Then, we propose two algorithms to numerically solve this optimization problem.
Finally, the simulation results are presented to demonstrate the performance improvement achieved by our proposed algorithm compared to existing solutions.

The research conducted numerical simulations of vortex dynamics in fractal cluster structure (FCCS) superconductors by solving the time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau equations under an external magnetic field.

FCCS has been proposed as a possible candidate to explain the origin of high-temperature superconducting copper oxides. It consists of randomly distributed clusters that are interconnected via Josephson coupling.
We found that when the applied current exceeds a certain threshold Ic(H), the resistivity increases rapidly, where H represents the strength of the external magnetic field.
This behavior can be understood by considering the motion of the vortices within the cluster.
In addition, we show that the critical current density Jc decreases gradually with the increase of temperature T.
Finally, we discuss how these results are related to experiments on high-temperature superconducting copper oxides.
The Kuiper Belt is the source region for most short-period comets, but its formation is still unclear.
We presented the results of N-body simulations, which indicate how collisions between planetary embryos in Neptune's feeding zone can produce objects with orbits similar to those currently observed.
The initial condition is based on planetary migration models, which show that Neptune migrated outward by about 30 astronomical units before being halted at its current position.
Our calculations indicate that the formation of the Kuiper Belt is due to the collisions and grinding of bodies comparable in size to Pluto (with a radius of about 1,000 kilometers).
This process produced a group of small celestial bodies with orbital eccentricities of up to 0.3.
The subsequent collision with Neptune caused some of these bodies to become scattered into highly elliptical orbits.
These results explain why there seems to be no correlation between the size distribution of KBOs and their orbital eccentricity.

We studied the temperature-dependent shape anisotropy effects in an exchange-coupled system composed of two identical single-axis single-domain particles. One of the particles has softer magnetism, and the easy magnetic axes of the two particles are parallel to each other.
We demonstrate that for certain parameter values, the coercive field increases significantly at low temperatures compared to high temperatures.

This can be understood by considering the competition between the Zeeman energy barrier caused by the applied magnetic field and the thermally activated energy barrier related to temperature-dependent shape anisotropy.
The model we are considering consists of two identical spherical particles (with a radius of R) that are separated by a distance d along the z-axis.
Each particle has its own uniaxial anisotropy constant Ks(T), where T represents the temperature.

Through coupling, they also exchange coupling via the coupling constant J. For simplicity, we assume that the anisotropy constants have the following identical functional form: Ks = K1 + K2 tanh[-(T/Tc)], where Tc is a characteristic temperature scale used to determine the rate at which anisotropy varies with temperature.

We propose an exact quantum mechanical treatment for describing the dynamics of open systems, in which the system is coupled to multiple harmonic oscillators that represent its surrounding environment.
We demonstrate that, under certain conditions, the model can be exactly simplified to a main equation in the Lindblad form.
The derived master equation is used to study the impact of environmental fluctuations on the evolution of the density matrix that describes the system's state.
Specifically, we consider two different environmental models corresponding to Ohmic dissipation and spin-boson interactions, respectively.

The two scenarios demonstrate how the influence of the environment leads to the irreversible loss of information about the initial state of the system and how, in the later stages, it results in thermalization.

Finally, we discuss the potential applications of our results in certain issues, such as the transport through mesoscopic conductors or the dissipative tunneling between localized states in disordered solids.
The processes of decoherence and relaxation play a crucial role in understanding the physics of open quantum systems.

Based on deep HST/ACS imaging data, we present new results regarding the properties and evolution of early-type galaxies (ETGs) in the Coma cluster. This data is part of our ongoing investigation of faint globular clusters associated with ETGs.
We found that most of the brightest members of the star clusters are elliptical galaxies or lenticular galaxies, and only one is classified as an S0/a galaxy.
The proportion of S0 increases as the brightness dims, reaching about 50% at MV = -18 mag.
This result indicates that most S0 galaxies formed through morphological transformations from late-type spiral galaxies as they fell into the cluster environment.

By comparing the observed number density distributions of globular clusters around different types of early universe galaxies, we demonstrate that there are no significant differences among these three populations.

In this work, the existence and stability of wormholes were investigated in the spacetime described by the exact solution of the gravitational field generated by a spherically symmetric object with axial symmetry, corresponding to the simplest case of a non-rotating black hole.

The Standard Model (SM) is a very successful theory, but it still leaves many unanswered questions in high-energy physics.

Specifically, there are currently no known fundamental principles to explain why the Standard Model has three generations of quarks and leptons with such different masses, or how gravity fits into this framework.
Theories that go beyond the standard model attempt to address these issues by introducing new particles and/or interactions, which may be observed in future experiments.
Supersymmetry (SUSY), as an example, introduces partners for all standard model (SM) fields, with their spins differing by half a unit.

These accompanying states have the same gauge quantum numbers as their corresponding states in the Standard Model, so if supersymmetry is broken at low energy scales, they can mix with the Standard Model states.
This mixture may lead to deviations between the observed quantities (such as cross sections and decay rates) and the predictions of the Standard Model.
Many extensions of the standard model also predict new phenomena related to additional spacetime dimensions.
For example, theories based on string theory/M-theory often include additional spatial dimensions that are compressed to a tiny size.

If these extra dimensions exist, then we should see evidence of their effects through the virtual exchange of gravitational and other particles that are Kaluza-Klein excitations between the localized standard model fields in the volume of our four-dimensional world.

We proposed an algorithm that can determine whether there exists a quantum circuit with a given number of qubits and gates such that the corresponding time-independent Hamiltonian can be realized by a physical system, where each energy level can have at most one excited state.
We also demonstrated how to find all possible circuits (if they exist).
Our results are based on recent studies, which indicate that any time-independent Hamiltonian can be expressed as a sum of mutually commuting projection operators onto its eigenstates.

This decomposition allows us to transform the problem of finding a general time-independent Hamiltonian into multiple instances of the same problem, but these instances are constrained within smaller Hilbert spaces.
This simplification results in a polynomial time algorithm when applied recursively.
Finally, we discuss some applications of our method, including determining the minimum depth required for a universal adiabatic quantum computer.

In this article, we consider the following question: Given a set of n qubits and m two-qubit gates, is there a quantum circuit composed solely of these gates, whose associated time-independent Hamiltonian is realizable; that is, does it correspond to a Hermitian operator acting on a finite-dimensional Hilbert space?
If that's the case, what is the minimum circuit size required?
The answer to this question will depend on the specifics of the model used to describe the physical system in question.
For example, in cases where each energy level may have multiple excited states (i.e., degeneracy), no circuit can implement the desired Hamiltonian, as it contains infinitely many gates.
On the other hand, if each energy level has exactly one excited state...
We analyzed the alignment of galaxy rotation and tidal fields in real space using two-dimensional redshift survey (TMRS) data.
We found that galaxies preferentially align perpendicular to their local tidal fields on scales larger than 1 Mpc/h.
This alignment is more pronounced in larger, more massive galaxies at higher redshifts.
The observed spin-tidal correlation can be explained by the gravitational torque effects of large-scale structures during the formation process of these galaxies.
Our results indicate that this mechanism may play an important role in shaping the angular momentum of the galaxy.
These findings are significant for understanding how dark matter halos acquire their angular momentum and for explaining the observational results of cosmic shear statistics.
Introduction: Galaxies form in regions of the universe with a high density, where they experience strong gravitational interactions with other objects, such as nearby galaxies or groups of galaxies.
During the formation process, these interactions can trigger gravitational torques, affecting the direction of the angular momentum vector of the galaxy.
Conversely, the direction of the angular momentum of the galaxy determines the shape of the galaxy through the process of dynamic friction.
Therefore, it has been suggested that the shape distribution of galaxies may provide information about the origin of galaxy angular momentum (e.g., Catelan & Theuns 1996; Lee et al. 2008).

However, observational studies have shown contradictory results, suggesting that there is no preferential relationship between the direction of the galaxy's rotation axis and its nearby positions (see, for example, recent studies by Faltenbacher et al. 2002; Bailin et al. 2005; Paz et al. 2008; Codis et al. 2012).
To understand the physical mechanism that determines the direction of angular momentum in galaxies, we need to study the statistical properties of the spin distribution of galaxies on a cosmic scale.
Recent surveys, such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), have enabled us to accurately measure the directions of galaxies, allowing for such analyses.
For example, Lee et al. (2008) studied the alignment relationship between the spin vectors of galaxies and the position angles of their nearest neighbors using SDSS DR4 data.

We propose a solar equation of state (EOS) model based on path integral formalism, which includes quantum nuclear effects appearing in shell corrections. These corrections are obtained by using realistic nuclear interactions for the calculations.

The EOS (equation of state) covers a density range from 0 to 1.5 times the normal density, with temperatures ranging from 10^6 K to 5×10^8 K. We compare our results with those obtained by other authors using different methods or approximations.
Our new EOS is consistent with previous calculations within their respective valid ranges, but extends these results into previously unexplored areas.
We found that the rate of pressure increase near the center of the Sun is much faster than predicted by the standard model.
This results in a higher central temperature and a smaller radius compared to the standard model.
These differences are important for understanding the structure of stars like the Sun and for modeling stellar evolution.
Keywords: Inside the Sun

We present new results on the faint-end slope and evolution of the luminosity function (LF) of optically selected quasars based on the VIMOS-VLT Deep Survey (VVDS) in the redshift range of 0.5 < z < 2.2.
We use two different methods to estimate the LF parameters for each redshift interval: the 1/Vmax method and the maximum likelihood fitting technique.
Our best fit value is obtained by combining these two techniques with Monte Carlo simulation.
We found that our data is consistent with previous studies within their uncertainty range.
However, we point out that there is a significant inconsistency between the number density of observed bright quasars and the predictions made using standard quasar formation models.
This may be due to the effects of incompleteness in the selection process or the bias that has been introduced.
In addition, we also studied the dependence of the low-frequency spectral shape on the optical luminosity of quasars.

We present the results of polarized radio emission observations in the region surrounding the Abell 2218 galaxy cluster, conducted using the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) at frequencies of 1.4 GHz and 4.8 GHz.
We detected 16 compact sources above 5 mJy beam⁻¹ at two frequencies; all sources, except for one, were unresolved or marginally resolved in our observations.
Most objects have a linear polarization degree between 10% and 20%, while the polarization degree of two objects is as high as 40%.
All detected sources seem to be associated with galaxies in the central region of Abell 2218.
In addition, we found evidence of diffuse polarized radiation around the brightest member of this galaxy cluster.

This is likely due to the synchrotron radiation produced by relativistic electrons, which are driven into the star cluster medium by oscillations generated during multiple merger processes, with the time range of these merger events spanning from 100 million years to several billion years.
Our data also reveals the extended halo-like structure surrounding the entire galaxy cluster.
We reported an anomalous flare detected by Swift/XRT approximately one day after the outburst, which lasted for over 100,000 seconds (about 20 hours).
After the flare, observations were conducted using XMM-Newton/EPIC-pn, covering the time range from 2.5 days to 3 months after the burst.

We find that this flare is best described as the superposition of two components: one component lasts for about 50 kiloseconds and peaks at around 10^-3 seconds; the other component lasts for about 70 kiloseconds and peaks at around 5 x 10^4 seconds. Both components fit well to an exponentially truncated power law, with photon indices of Γ = -1.6 ± 0.1 and -2.2 ± 0.3, respectively.
There is no obvious spectral evolution detected in these two flares.
This flare is one of the strongest energies observed in any gamma-ray burst to date.
We theoretically studied the effect of the longitudinal magnetic field in the coronal ring on the damping rate of small amplitude flare oscillations.

We found that for sufficiently large longitudinal magnetic field values, the damping is mainly dominated by resonance absorption, and it increases with the increase in longitudinal magnetic field strength.
For smaller values of the vertical magnetic field, we find that the damping is caused by the phase mixing between Alfven waves propagating along neighboring magnetic flux tubes.
In this case, the damping decreases with the weakening of the longitudinal magnetic field.
The results were compared with observations made by the Solar Ultraviolet Radiation Measurement (SUMER) instrument on the SOHO spacecraft.

Since the early 1980s, it has been observed that many solar flares exhibit a periodic lateral displacement, which can be observed in Hα images as well as in EUV spectral lines formed at higher layers than Hα.
The period of these movements ranges from a few minutes to about one minute, with amplitudes typically less than 100 kilometers per second.

The theoretical model suggests that these oscillations may be triggered by slow magnetoacoustic waves trapped inside the flare's main body, or by fast bending modes excited by photospheric flows (see, for example, Oliver & Ballester 1994).

We present the results of the flame evolution during the explosion of Type Ia supernovae (SN), which are based on two-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations and a detailed nuclear reaction network that encompasses both deflagration and detonation.

We found that the transition to detonation is triggered by shock-induced turbulent mixing at a density of approximately \(10^{9} \, \text{g/cm}^3\). The detonation wave propagates through the entire white dwarf about one second after ignition.
In this case, if we assume an initial central density of 2 x $10^8$ g/cm$^3$ or higher, we can reproduce the observed light curve.
At lower central density values, the explosion failed to produce sufficient 56Ni to account for the observational results.

We reported the observation of the dynamic condensation of water vapor at the crack tip during slow fracture experiments conducted under low temperature (77 K) and vacuum conditions (10^-6 mbar).
Condensed water was found to be limited to the crack front, forming a thin film that covers the entire surface of the crack tip.
This phenomenon has been observed in cracks that propagate either perpendicularly or parallel to the direction of maximum tensile stress.
We propose a model based on molecular dynamics simulations, which explains this effect by considering the electric field generated by the moving crack tip.
In addition, we also demonstrate how the formation of this film will affect the mechanical properties of the material.
The phenomenon of condensation is common in nature, but it has rarely been reported in materials science.
We present experimental evidence here indicating that when a crack propagates in molten quartz glass, water condenses on the surface of the crack.
These results were obtained by combining optical microscopy, environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM), Raman spectroscopy, and infrared reflection-absorption spectroscopy (IRAS).
We study the lattice chiral gauge theory of four-dimensional Wilson fermions, focusing on its phase structure at finite temperature T.
We demonstrate that if the number of flavors \( N_f \) satisfies \( N_f > 2 \), then there is no spontaneous parity (P) or time-reversal symmetry (T) breaking at any bare quark mass \( m_0 \).
This result implies that the theory does not have any order parameters related to P and/or T, which are spontaneously broken by the standard model.
In particular, we found that the spectrum contains two types of degenerate Dirac fermions, corresponding to left-handed and right-handed quarks, respectively.
These fermions can be identified as mirror fermions, as they can transform into each other under reflection across a spatial axis.
The existence of these mirror Fermions has led to some interesting consequences, such as the absence of flavor-changing neutral currents mediated by gluons.

We present the chemical abundance data of stars in three globular clusters (M92, M15, and M68) located in the halo, based on high-resolution spectra obtained using the HIRES spectrograph at the Keck Observatory.
We found that the abundance patterns of these star clusters are very similar to those observed in the field halo stars; they are both metal-poor and α-enhanced systems.
The average [Fe/H] value we obtained ranges from -2.3 dex to -1.9 dex, depending on the cluster considered.

These results confirm the previous suggestion that there may be no significant differences between the characteristics of stellar populations within individual open clusters or globular clusters and those of the general characteristics of the galactic halo star group.
Moreover, our estimated ages indicate that these star clusters formed early in the formation history of the Milky Way.
Finally, we will compare the kinematics of these star clusters with other nearby halo objects, such as dwarf galaxies and ultra-faint dwarf galaxies.
We proposed an algorithm for constructing a discrete computer network in which each node is connected to all nodes within a certain distance, as well as to some other nodes that are farther away.
As you move away from the node along any path, the number of additional connections increases exponentially.
We indicate that this feature can be used to construct efficient routing tables for such networks.
Our results are based on a new concept called "expanded dimensions."
This concept allows us to define a natural hierarchy for the nodes in the network.

Specifically, we prove that if there exists a polynomial-time algorithm for finding the shortest path between two given nodes, then there must exist another polynomial-time algorithm for solving the same problem, but restricted to pairs of nodes whose distances fall within a specific range.
Finally, we discuss the possible applications of these ideas in the context of distributed computing problems.
Keywords: computer networks, extended dimensions, hierarchy, routing.
We study the transitions of heavy quark states to hybrid mesons using the multipole expansion method within the framework of a non-relativistic potential model.
We calculate the decay widths of various types of transitions, including E1, M1, E2, M2, E3, M3, E4, M4, as well as the S-wave meson emission process.
The results were compared with existing experimental data and theoretical predictions based on other methods, such as lattice gauge theory.
In addition, we determine the mass spectrum of the hybrids by numerically solving the Schrödinger equation.
The research found that the mass we calculated corresponds well with the mass obtained recently through lattice gauge theory, showing a reasonable consistency.
Finally, we discuss the possible mechanisms for producing mixed states in future experiments.
This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China, grant number 10675040.
We thank Professors J. H. Chen and C. T. Chan for their valuable discussions.

We presented very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) images and light curves at 8.4 GHz related to the supernova remnant (SNR) associated with the type IIb supernova SN2004et. This supernova exploded on September 24, 2004, in the nearby spiral galaxy NGC 6946.
Radio wave radiation is dominated by two bright components, which are separated by about 0.5 arcseconds during all observation periods from January 2005 to December 2007.
We found that the expansion speed of both components is approximately 5000 km/s, which is consistent with earlier estimates based on single-disk data.
However, we also found that the actual motion speed of each component during this period was about 1000 kilometers per second.
These results indicate that the age of the supernova remnant is approximately 3 years, which means that the distance to NGC 6946 is 4 Mpc.
This value is clearly smaller than the distance of the object estimated using other methods previously.
Our measurements provide new constraints for the core-collapse supernova model.
Keywords: Supernova Remnants

We conducted first-principles calculations using density functional theory with Van der Waals corrections to investigate the structure, energy, and dynamics of water adsorbed on the MgO(001) surface under sub-monolayer conditions.
We found that the most stable structure is formed when each oxygen atom is bonded to three hydrogen atoms, creating a trihydrogen bridge between two adjacent oxygen atoms.

The binding energy of each molecule in this configuration is 1.6 electron volts. This value is consistent with theoretical results obtained previously under the generalized gradient approximation, but there is a significant difference compared to experimental values, which are typically about 0.5 to 0.7 electron volts higher. Our calculations indicate that this difference can be primarily attributed to the neglect of dispersion interactions in earlier studies.
In addition, we also studied the impact of temperature on the stability of different configurations.
We found that the relative quantities of different structures strongly depend on temperature.

We studied the propagation of sound waves through a one-dimensional (1D) Bose-Einstein condensate gas, which is confined by an optical lattice potential and interacts with each other through contact interactions.

Extracting freshwater and energy from the atmosphere has been proposed as an alternative method to traditional sources due to the limited supply of traditional sources or their detrimental effects on the environment.

This process involves using solar energy to condense moisture from the atmosphere into liquid water, and then collecting this water on surfaces coated with hydrophobic materials that allow the water to be easily transported by airflow.
This technology will provide clean drinking water to remote communities without the need for large land areas or infrastructure investments.

The measurement micro Calculus is an extension of the standard framework of quantum mechanics, which allows for the measurement of composite systems and has been applied in some recent studies and in this paper.
The main idea of measuring calculus is to regard all possible results of the measurement process as independent states of the measured system, rather than just a single outcome (as von Neumann did).
This method naturally leads us to consider the set of all possible measurement outcomes, which is referred to as the new state space of the effect algebra.
In addition, measurement calculus provides a method to describe how different measurement processes are combined into more complex measurement processes through so-called instrument combinations.

Finally, the measurement of calculus also includes a description of what happens when we measure a system for which we are not completely certain about a state, but can only measure within a certain range of uncertainty.
The concept of measure calculus was first proposed by Aharonov and others, and since then, many papers have been published regarding its properties and applications.

Cataclysmic variable stars (CVs) are a type of interacting binary system in which a white dwarf as the primary star accretes material from its low-mass companion star through Roche lobe overflow. They are one of the most studied categories of close binary stars.

They provide a unique opportunity to study various aspects of astrophysics, such as stellar structure and evolution, mass transfer processes, nuclear burning at high temperatures, and relativistic effects near compact objects.
In particular, they provide insights into the formation mechanisms of single and double degenerate white dwarfs, which are the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae.

The geometry of time is the discipline that studies how spacetime evolves with time.
The axiom of choice states that for any non-empty set of sets, there exists at least one set that contains exactly one element from each of the sets.

The geometry of time is a mathematical description of how spacetime evolves over time.
It was first introduced into physics by Hermann Minkowski.
"Who indicated that the geometry of spacetime can be represented by four numbers (x, y, z, t), which are called coordinates."
This is related to the following equation: x² + y² - z² - t² = (c²)(1 - (v/c))¹/₂, where c represents the speed of light and v represents the speed of the observed object.
This equation describes the relationship of distances traveled along the x-axis, y-axis, z-axis, and t-axis.

For example, if you observe someone walking across your living room floor with their back to you, their value on the x-axis will be positive, but there will be no values on the other three axes because they are not moving in those directions.
If you observe them walking away from you, their values on all three axes will be negative, except for the x-axis, because they are still moving forward in that direction.
Another example is to consider two objects moving side by side along the road.
They will all travel at the same speed, so their speeds will be equal.
However, if one car is traveling north while another car is traveling south, they will appear to be moving faster relative to each other, even though they are traveling at the same speed.

We reported the valley-related optoelectronic properties in monolayer WSe2, a semiconductor with strong spin-orbit coupling and large exciton binding energy that breaks inversion symmetry.
We demonstrate that circularly polarized light can control the valley polarization of optically excited carriers through light pumping at room temperature.

The dynamic-based method is an emerging approach to studying exoplanets, which are planets with masses similar to that of Earth, orbiting other stars outside of our solar system.
The main goal of this research is to study how these planets form and evolve over time.
This method uses numerical simulation to model the formation and evolution of celestial bodies in planetary systems, addressing the equations of motion that describe gravitational interactions.
In addition, it also takes into account physical processes such as tidal dissipation, collisions between asteroids (small rocky objects), and atmospheric escape.
By adopting this approach, we can better understand how our own planet formed billions of years ago and the conditions necessary for life to develop on Earth.
Keywords: Planetary Science; Astrobiology; Tidal Dissipation; Collisions Between Small Bodies; Atmosphere Escape.

It simulates the formation and evolution of the entire planetary system through numerical models, specifically by solving equations that describe the orbital motion of celestial bodies under mutual gravitational interactions.
In addition, it also includes physical processes such as tidal dissipation, collisions between asteroids (smaller rocky objects), and atmospheric escape.
By adopting this method, scientists hope to understand how our planet formed billions of years ago and the environmental factors necessary for life to exist there.

"Fostering Breakthroughs" is a book co-authored by James Watson and Peter Winkler, which discusses how to create breakthroughs in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering, or Mathematics (STEM).
The authors believe that the best way for scientists to make new discoveries is not to rely on individual genius, but to work through teamwork to solve the problems they are passionate about.
They also claim that having a rough understanding of what the problem looks like before you start addressing it can be helpful, as this will guide your research work.
This article describes some of their ideas and provides examples of how these concepts can be applied to scientific research.
In his book "Nurturing Breakthroughs," James Watson believes that the most successful people in solving complex problems do so through collaboration with others rather than trying to work alone.

He said that when we work alone, our brains often focus only on one aspect of the problem at hand, which can lead us into dead ends. In contrast, working collaboratively allows us to see all aspects of the problem at the same time.

Supersymmetry is one of the most promising extensions beyond the Standard Model, addressing many unresolved issues such as the hierarchy problem between the electroweak scale and the Planck scale, as well as the unification of forces.
Through supplementation, it provides a natural candidate for cold dark matter—the lightest neutrino.
The minimal supersymmetric standard model (MSSM) has been widely studied over the past two decades, but it still has several shortcomings.
One reason is that the Standard Model fails to explain why there are three generations of quarks and leptons with different quantum numbers.

The Grand Unified Theories (GUTs) address this issue by hypothesizing that all known particles, including those of the third generation, belong to a multiple representation of a symmetry group that is larger than SU(3) x SU(2) x U(1).
This naturally introduces the relationship between the coupling constant and the fermion mass matrix.
Another drawback of the MSSM is that it cannot explain the experimentally observed small neutrino masses.
However, if R symmetry is broken, then Majorana neutrinos may acquire a small mass through the seesaw mechanism.

We studied how different assumptions about the velocity distribution function (VDF) affect the shape of the spectral line profiles observed in the solar corona, using an analytical model that incorporates both isotropic thermal motion and anisotropic non-thermal motion in the velocity distribution function.

We found that considering the effects of non-thermal motion can significantly change the shape of the simulated line profile compared to the results obtained under the assumption of a pure Maxwellian distribution.

We consider an antenna combination scheme where each user is equipped with multiple antennas and uses space-time coding technology to transmit their data to a base station (BS).

We proposed an algorithm for unicast and multicast quality of service (QoS) routing on the internet using Soft Constraint Logic Programming (SCLP).
The proposed method is based on the concept that each node maintains its own view of the network topology, which may differ from the views of other nodes due to link failures or congestion.
We use SCLP as our foundational framework because it can naturally represent inconsistent information between nodes.
In addition, we demonstrate how to incorporate bandwidth constraints into the SCLP model by introducing a new variable that represents the available bandwidth between two adjacent links.
Finally, we propose several algorithms to effectively solve this problem.

1 Introduction  
The age of stars plays a crucial role in many fields of astrophysics, from galactic archaeology to exoplanet science.
Accurate age data is particularly needed to understand how planets form and evolve over time.
However, determining the exact age of individual celestial bodies remains challenging, as they span multiple orders of magnitude in mass and luminosity and exhibit complex evolutionary histories.

For example, although the age of a main-sequence star can be accurately determined using photometric techniques, such as fitting theoretical isochrones to a color-magnitude diagram (CMD), these methods become difficult to extend beyond the red giant branch, as the influence of convection becomes significant at that point.
In addition, although stellar seismology allows us to probe the interiors of evolving stars, interpreting the obtained data requires detailed modeling of the structure and evolution of each star.
Therefore, it is necessary to explore other methods to determine the ages of a large number of celestial bodies at different stages of evolution.

Gyrochronology provides another method for estimating the ages of celestial bodies based on the rotational deceleration rates associated with magnetic activity cycles, which are driven by the dynamo processes located at the base of the solar convection zone (Barnes 2003).
It has been shown that the Rossby number \( R_o \) is defined as the ratio of the rotation period \( P_{rot} \) to the time scale of convective turnover.
We proposed a reliability analysis method that has a hierarchical structure and can be applied to any cache-based storage architecture.
The main idea of our method is to use a set of models at different levels of abstraction to represent the system under study.
We demonstrated how to combine these models with simulation experiments to conduct a reliability assessment of a cache-based commercial RAID storage architecture.
Our research results indicate that this method has significant advantages over traditional approaches that are solely based on analytical models or simulation experiments.

In particular, we find that: (1) it enables us to obtain accurate estimates of reliability metrics, such as mean time between failures; (2) it allows us to explore trade-offs among various design parameters; and (3) it helps us identify key components within the system.
Finally, we discussed some limitations of our method and suggested directions for future research.
Caching has been widely adopted in modern computer systems to improve performance by reducing access latency.
However, caching introduces new challenges related to data consistency management and fault tolerance.
This article proposes a new method for reliability analysis based on cache storage architecture.

The observed spectrum can be described by a power law model, which is modified for photoelectric absorption and emission lines at around 1 keV energy.
We found that this object has shown significant changes in various observations conducted over the years.
In addition to these features, we detected a soft excess below 2 keV.
This feature cannot be explained solely by the hot plasma model or reflection components, but requires additional contributions from ionized absorbers and/or partially covering neutral material.
Using the best-fit model for our time-averaged dataset, we obtained the intrinsic luminosities Lx(2-10 keV) = 4 x 10^43 erg s^-1 and Lx(0.5-2 keV) = 5 x 10^44 erg s^-1.
These values are typical for powerful FR II radio galaxies.

Recently, the debate about the future supply of fossil fuels has raised concerns about the impact of "peak oil" (the maximum extraction rate that is economically feasible) on global warming, particularly in relation to the emission targets set by the Kyoto Protocol.

In this study, we use a comprehensive assessment model that encompasses economic growth and energy supply-demand dynamics to examine how different assumptions about the timing and scale of peak oil affect the projected levels of carbon dioxide (CO2), temperature changes, and sea level rise by 2100 under business-as-usual conditions.
We found that if the peak oil is reached before 2020, the impact on these variables will be minimal, as there will still be time to develop alternative energy sources.

From this work, we studied how the evolution of the so-called Carter constant depends on the spin and mass ratio of black holes in a binary system that includes two rotating black holes.
The Carter constant is one of several motion constants related to geodesic orbits around Kerr black holes (Carter 1968).

It is used as a probe of the spacetime geometry close to the event horizon, as its value will only change significantly over time when there is a notable deviation from spherical symmetry at small radii (Bardeen, 1973; Thorne et al., 1986).
For example, even if the total angular momentum of the system remains constant, the presence of a massive accretion disk can lead to changes in the Carter constant (Kerr 1963).

Previous research has shown that the orbital evolution of binary stars with non-spin components is influenced by the quadrupole moment of black holes, Q = M(1 − S²)/c²R², where S represents the dimensionless spin parameter of each black hole (Damour & Nagar 1999).

On the other hand, recent observations have shown that many galactic nuclei contain supermassive black holes, with masses reaching up to 10^9 solar masses (for example, Gebhardt et al. (2000)).

In such an evolutionary process, black holes can acquire a significant amount of angular momentum and/or through tidal interactions.

We report observations of a large-scale coronal mass ejection (CME) associated with the circular flare that occurred on December 13, 2006, in active region NOAA 10486, which was observed by the Solar-Terrestrial Relations Observatory (STEREO).
According to STEREO observations, the speed of the CME is estimated to be about 1450 kilometers per second at 1 astronomical unit.
We found that this coronal mass ejection (CME) originates from a complex magnetic structure that comprises two opposing polarity flux systems connected by a filament channel.
Additionally, we found that before the onset of flare/coronal mass ejection activities, there were several small-scale brightening phenomena around the main sunspots.
These brightened areas are called ephemeral regions (ERs) and are known to play an important role in triggering eruptions such as flares or coronal mass ejections.

By analyzing the high-resolution images taken by Hinode/SOT/SP, we show that one of these enhanced regions (ER) interacts strongly with the surrounding magnetic field lines during the rapid rotation process.
This interaction leads to the reconnection between open and closed magnetic fields, thereby forming a current sheet below the ER.
Then, when the current sheet becomes unstable due to twist instability, the eruption begins.

The solar chromosphere is an important component of our understanding of how the Sun operates and its effects on Earth, but it has been difficult to study due to its tenuous nature. The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) may be able to observe this region for the first time with unprecedented spatial resolution.
This presentation will discuss some scientific research achievements obtained from observations of the solar chromosphere using ALMA.
The solar chromosphere is one of the most mysterious regions of the Sun.
It is located near the photosphere and the corona, and plays a key role in transporting energy to the upper atmosphere.

However, due to its extremely low density, it was only recently possible to directly observe the solar chromosphere using high-resolution images obtained from space telescopes such as the Hinode/SOT and the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO/AIA).

In addition, significant progress has been made in ground observation stations in studying the corona through various techniques such as spectral polarization measurement, imaging spectroscopy, and speckle interferometry.
Despite these advancements, there are still many unresolved questions regarding the physical processes occurring within the color sphere that need further exploration.
For example, what causes the formation of dynamic structures like sunspots?
How does the magnetic field influence plasma dynamics in the chromosphere?
What is the relationship between the heating mechanism of the chromosphere and coronal mass ejections?
These questions cannot be answered without a detailed understanding of the structure and dynamics of the solar system.
To address these issues, we need new observational data with higher spatial resolution than ever before.
The perovskite MgSiO3 has been studied through first-principles calculations and semi-empirical P-V-T equations of state (EOS).

The calculation results indicate that MgSiO3 perovskite has a high bulk modulus, low compressibility, a large volumetric thermal expansion coefficient at high temperatures, and a small thermal expansion rate compared to other oxides.
These characteristics are very important for understanding geophysical phenomena, such as earthquakes and volcanic activity.
In addition to these physical properties, we also used density functional theory (DFT) methods to study the electronic structure of magnesium silicate perovskite.
We found that there is charge transfer between Si4+ ions and O2- ions, which leads to the formation of Si-O bonds.
This charge transfer leads to changes in the bond lengths and bond angles within the Si-O-Si network.
Finally, we discussed the impact of oxygen vacancies on the stability of the MgSiO3 perovskite structure.

The layout problem is formulated as an optimization problem: given a set of objects that need to be stored in memory, we want to find their positions so that future queries can access them in the most efficient way.
In this work, we consider the following scenario: a large amount of data needs to be stored in the main memory (for example, a database).
The data consists of many small objects (such as records) that vary greatly in size; some objects may even exceed the available space.
To solve this problem, a standard technique known as "chunking" can be used: divide each object into equally sized chunks and then place these chunks sequentially in the allocated storage area.

However, if the number of blocks for each object is too few, it will not be able to fully fit into the allocated blocks; similarly, if the number of blocks for each object is too many, the unused space between them cannot be effectively utilized.

We present the clustering properties of star-forming galaxies at redshifts approximately 1, 2, and 3 within the area of the GALEX Deep Imaging Survey (DIS), using photometric redshifts obtained by combining deep optical data from the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS).
We use two different methods to select our galaxy sample: one based on their observed NUV flux, and the other based on the intrinsic star formation rate (SFR) estimated from their UV luminosity.

We evaluate the predictive capabilities of galaxy formation models by comparing their predictions of the static optical luminosity function (LFs) with observational results in the redshift range z=2-3.

We use two different semi-analytical models, GALFORM and L-GALAXIES, to predict the number density of galaxies, as well as the distribution evolution of stellar mass and star formation rate within this redshift range.
The predicted LF was directly compared with the observational data obtained from the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) using the Hubble Space Telescope.
In addition, we compared the observed and predicted absolute ultraviolet magnitudes and the color distribution after dust correction.

We reported the unusual temperature dependence of the resistance transition width in MgB2 single crystals grown via the chemical vapor transport (CVT) method, as well as its scaling relationship with the applied magnetic field.

The observed behavior is explained within the framework of vortex pinning induced by fluctuations, which leads to a decrease in the effective volume fraction contributing to the resistance in the sample at low temperatures.
This effect becomes more pronounced as the external magnetic field strength increases.
We seek evidence for this situation by studying the anisotropy of the magnetoresistance as well as the upper critical fields Hc2(0) and Hc3(0), where we observe a strong increase at low temperatures.

We present the results of a subjective evaluation experiment conducted on forms designed for immersive environments such as virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR).
The goal is to investigate users' perceptions of different forms of design when immersed in these environments.
We compared three designs: the traditional two-dimensional form, the three-dimensional form rendered with perspective projection, and the three-dimensional form rendered with orthographic projection.
Our research results show that there is no significant difference between the two types of three-dimensional forms.
However, the ratings for these two 3D forms are significantly higher than their 2D counterparts.
This indicates that 3D forms can be effectively used in immersive environments without the need for special rendering techniques or additional hardware.
In addition, we found that participants preferred forms that had more visual cues to indicate depth information, rather than those that did not have any such cues.
Finally, our research also indicates that it is possible to create effective forms by combining elements from multiple existing designs.

We reexamine the foundations of quantum mechanics by introducing an alternative formulation based on the concept of dynamic phase transition (DPT), rather than using the standard Feynman path integral method.
We indicate that this new formalism provides a natural description for the emergence and evolution of macroscopic order in open quantum systems.

In particular, we demonstrate how it is used to describe the process of spontaneous emission in atomic physics, where the interaction between atoms and the field leads to the formation of collective states that have distinct photon number statistics.
The proposed framework also allows us to study the dynamics of many-body interaction systems beyond mean field theory.
Finally, we discussed the potential applications of our results in condensed matter physics and quantum information science.

We present new results on the kinematics and dynamics of the circumnuclear region (CNR) of NGC 1097, based on integral field spectroscopy observations with SINFONI at VLT/UT4.

We found that the CNR is primarily dominated by two components: an inner disk-like structure that extends to about 1 kpc in radius, and a component that flows out rapidly along a position angle of approximately 45°, extending to a location about 5 kpc from the nucleus.
The latter shows a blueshifted emission line, indicating that the radial velocity relative to the system is between -500 km/s and -1000 km/s.
This type of outflow has been detected previously through data from the Integral Field Unit (IFU) and images from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).

Using a simple gas distribution and kinematic model, we estimate that the mass inflow rate into the CNR ranges from 0.1 M⊙ per year to several solar masses per year.

We report the discovery of a new satellite galaxy called "ApoBootes," which orbits around our Milky Way at a distance of approximately 300 kiloparsecs, with an estimated mass of 1.5 x 10^10 solar masses.
ApoBootes is located opposite the center of the Milky Way, far from the Magellanic Clouds, and has a very low surface brightness.

The luminosity characteristics are consistent with the expected properties of dwarf elliptical galaxies.

This book aims to introduce the relevant physical and mathematical foundations of how proteins fold into their natural three-dimensional structures.

This book is not only useful for graduate students studying biophysics, but it is also helpful for researchers interested in interdisciplinary issues, such as pattern formation or self-assembly processes.

By conducting direct numerical simulations in a cylindrical geometry with periodic boundary conditions, the effects of magnetic Reynolds number (Rm), Lundquist number (S), and plasma β (β) on the efficiency of MRI-driven turbulence were studied.
The results indicate that Rm, S, and β have a significant impact on the saturation level of the Maxwell stress tensor and the growth rate of kinetic energy density.

Specifically, it was discovered that with other parameters held constant, increasing Rm leads to an increase in both the saturation value of the Maxwell stress tensor and the growth rate of the total energy density.
Increasing S will also increase the saturation value of the stress tensor, but it does not affect its growth rate.
On the contrary, reducing β will decrease the saturation value of the tensor while having almost no effect on its growth rate.
It should be noted that these trends are only observed when the initial equilibrium state satisfies certain constraints depending on the dimensionless numbers considered.

We present the first results of a new family of templates, SEOBNRv4HM, which is designed to detect gravitational waves (GW) emitted by binary black holes of comparable masses, with a total mass between 10 and 100 solar masses.

Abstract: We consider the issue of gravitational interactions between objects from the perspective of information content.

The main point here is that a gravitational field can be viewed as a collection of gravitons/quantons, which carry information about the source; gravitational waves are seen as carriers of information about the motion state of gravitational entities.

This viewpoint allows us to provide explanations for certain phenomena observed in astrophysical environments (such as the Pioneer anomaly) as well as phenomena within the cosmological context (such as dark energy).
In addition, we suggest using the concept of "information potential" to describe the evolution of the universe.

We propose that the observed metallicity enhancement in some post-T Tauri stars (PTTS) may be due to the accretion of planetesimals during their formation phase, followed by the rapid formation of planets and the ejection of these planets into space.

We indicate that this scenario can explain the high metallicity found in PTTS, as well as the low abundance ratios of refractory elements (such as Mg/Si or Al/Si) compared to what is expected for objects formed through standard nuclear fusion processes.
The proposed mechanism also explains why there are no known close-in giant planets around PTTS, despite having gone through the protoplanetary disk phase.
This model predicts that most PTTS should have at least one Jupiter-mass planet orbiting on a wide orbit beyond 1 AU.
In addition, we predict that many brown dwarfs around planets (PTTS) will exhibit infrared excess caused by dust debris disks resulting from collisions between planetary bodies.

We used the IRAC instrument of the Spitzer Space Telescope for the first time to conduct mid-infrared phase curve observations of the exoplanet WASP-121b (1SWASP J140747.93-394542.7) at the 3.6 micron and 4.5 micron wavelengths.
The data was collected over two time periods separated by one year, so that we could explore how the system properties change over time.

This indicates that as the planet revolves around its star, the temperature structure or composition does not change significantly.
Our results also indicate that the planet has a very high albedo in both bands, which may be due to clouds and/or haze.
These findings are significant for understanding how planets form and evolve.
Keywords: exoplanets, infrared

We propose an algorithm for generating new solutions to the coupled Einstein-scalar field equations, starting from vacuum solutions and adding a scalar field in such a way that the resulting solutions become minimally coupled.

The method can be used to generate exact solutions for certain parameters, which are not explicitly known, or are only known as implicit functions of certain parameters (for example, by solving algebraic equations).

We illustrate our method through several examples, including the Schwarzschild-de Sitter black hole, the Reissner-Nordström-anti-de Sitter black hole, the Kerr-Newman-AdS black hole, and the charged expanding black hole.
In particular, we demonstrate how to obtain explicit expressions for these black hole solutions in the massless limit.
Our results may have applications beyond gravitational theory; for example, in quantum mechanics, they can provide insights into the structure of bound states.
Introduction: Exact solutions play an important role in theoretical physics because they allow us to compare and test various physical ideas against concrete predictions.
However, finding precise solutions to physically interesting problems is often very difficult.
For example, it took more than 100 years to find the first exact solution for a black hole after the discovery of general relativity [1-3].
Even today, there are still many unanswered questions about black holes.
One reason why finding exact solutions is so challenging is that most interesting theories do not admit any simple analytical solutions.
Another issue arises when attempting to find solutions that describe systems with multiple interacting components, such as black holes surrounded by matter or other fields.
Here, numerical methods are usually required to solve complex differential equations, which makes it difficult to find all possible solutions even if their existence is theoretically guaranteed.

If you want to study phenomena under strong coupling, this situation becomes particularly severe, because in this case, numerical methods become less reliable due to the large corrections from higher-order perturbation theory.

Abstract: We present new asteroseismic analysis results from the main-sequence F-type star α Centauri A, which forms a close binary system with its cooler companion star B.

Our research is based on over four years of high-precision radial velocity measurement data collected using the HARPS instrument on the 3.6-meter telescope at the La Silla Observatory in the Andes Mountains of Chile, combined with photometric observations conducted simultaneously with the CoRoT space mission.

Using standard techniques applied in stellar asteroseismology, we have detected several periodic signals in both datasets, one of which has a periodicity that precisely corresponds to the orbital period of the system.
This discovery confirms the previous suggestion that the pulsating behavior of this star may be influenced by tidal effects induced by its companion star.
Through additional analysis, our study revealed another set of signals, corresponding to a period range of approximately 1 day to nearly 2 days.
These signals can be interpreted as due to the oscillations of rotationally split p modes excited in the convective outer shell of the star.
Their presence provides strong support for the following hypothesis: The surface of Alpha Centauri A is shaped by magnetic activity driven by generator processes operating within convective zones.

Quantum repeaters have been proposed to overcome losses in quantum communication channels by utilizing entangled photons and linear optical elements, such as beam splitters, phase shifters, and single-photon detectors.
From this work, we demonstrate an experimental demonstration of a quantum relay composed of two remote nodes connected by 50 kilometers of optical fiber.

The system consists of three parts: (1) generating photon pairs from each node; (2) transmitting the photon pairs; (3) detecting the photon pairs; (4) performing Bell state measurements between two nodes; (5) performing feedforward operations on the received qubits based on the results of the Bell state measurements.
We have successfully demonstrated all of these components, except for the feedforward operation, which is still in development.
Our results indicate that the current setup can generate high-quality entanglement at distances of up to 50 kilometers.
This experiment paves the way for the practical application of quantum networks.

In this lecture, we will discuss the relationship between loop spaces and Langlands parameters, with a focus on their connections to representation theory.
We can start by reviewing some basic facts about loop spaces and their relationship with infinite-dimensional Lie groups (such as loop groups).
Next, we will review how to associate a certain type of infinite-dimensional Lie group, called an affine Hecke algebra, with any reductive algebraic group over a field \( k \) of characteristic 0.
In the end, we will explain how these two ideas are related through the concept of Harish-Chandra double modules.

The main result is that if \( G \) is a connected semisimple complex algebraic group defined over \( Q \), then there is a natural isomorphism between the category of finite-dimensional representations of \( G(Q) \) and the category of Harish-Chandra modules associated with the relevant affine Hecke algebra.

The Large Area Telescope (LAT) is one of the two instruments onboard the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), which was launched in June 2008.
The LAT consists of a set of silicon strip trackers and cesium iodide energy counters, capable of detecting gamma rays with energies ranging from 20 MeV to over 300 GeV.

These results were compared with the ground calibration measurements conducted before the launch.

We suggest that the energy release process in coronal mass ejections (CMEs) is due to two different physical mechanisms: magnetic reconnection and catastrophic loss of equilibrium driven by ideal magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) instabilities.
The first mechanism is the release of free magnetic energy stored in the corona as kinetic energy of plasma flow during solar explosive events, such as flares or coronal mass ejections.

This mechanism has been extensively studied through numerical simulations of magnetorheological fluid dynamics models with varying levels of complexity, ranging from simple two-dimensional configurations to more realistic three-dimensional configurations.
In this work, we focus on the second mechanism, which involves the rapid conversion of magnetic field energy into thermal energy through the explosive reconstruction of magnetic topology.
We demonstrate how to perform analytical modeling of this mechanism within the framework of ideal magnetohydrodynamics theory.
Our results indicate that these two processes may occur simultaneously, but at different evolutionary stages of the eruptive magnetic flux rope.

These young massive clusters (YMCs) can have a mass of up to 10^8 solar masses and a size of about 1 kiloparsec.

We present the results of a numerical study on the relaxation dynamics of a contact line, initially a straight line, in two-dimensional geometry. This dynamics is driven by surface tension and viscous dissipation on the moving interface between the liquid phase and the gas phase.

We use the spectral element method to solve the Navier-Stokes equations for incompressible fluids, employing free-slip boundary conditions to simulate the flow field around the continuously changing shape of droplets.

We consider the problem of estimating the unknown function f from the noise measurement y = Af + w, where A is a linear operator and w is white noise with a known covariance matrix Cw.
We assume that operator A has been discretized on a certain grid (for example, by using finite difference methods or spectral methods) so that it can be expressed as a large matrix.
The goal is to find an estimate \( f \) such that \( E[f] - f^2 \) is minimized under certain smoothness constraints.
From this work, we propose a new numerical technique based on demand wavelets that can effectively solve these constrained optimization problems.

Specifically, our method enables us to obtain accurate estimates even when the number of available observations N is much smaller than the dimensionality M of the space spanned by the columns of A. The proposed method relies on two main components:
First, we use a sparse representation to express functions in terms of the required wavelets.
Secondly, we developed efficient iterative algorithms for solving large-scale convex optimization problems involving sparse-encouraging regularization.
These algorithms combine the ideas of compressed sensing theory with the latest results on the convergence rates of the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM).

We present the spectroscopic follow-up results of eight galaxy clusters selected from the Red Sequence Cluster Survey (RCS) at redshift z = 0.6-0.9.
The sample consists of four X-ray luminous groups and four optically rich groups, with a mass range of M500 = 1.5 × 10^14 - 2.7 × 10^14 h70M⊙.
We obtained spectra for over 100 star cluster members using the VLT/FORS2 and Keck/DEIMOS spectrographs.
Based on these data, we derive the velocity dispersion, dynamical mass estimates, and luminosity-weighted ages for each system.
To complement this analysis, we also studied the evolution of scale relations as redshift changes up to z = 1.1.
Our results indicate that the observed characteristics are consistent with the expectations of experiencing gravitational collapse in a massive system.

We present new observations from the Chandra X-ray Observatory and spectral observations of the galaxy cluster Abell 576, which is known to have two merging components separated by about 1 arcminute (approximately 700 kpc).

The northern component was previously studied as an example of a "line-of-sight bullet cluster"; it shows no significant substructure or evidence of shock heating in the line-of-sight direction, but does exhibit signs of recent merger activity on smaller scales.

On the contrary, we found that the southern component appeared very relaxed, with few signs of disturbance; however, this might be due to the projection effect, as there are several galaxies farther away from the center of the cluster whose redshifts indicate they are located behind the core of the cluster.
We also detected diffuse emissions extending to a halo radius of two clusters, which may indicate that these systems are undergoing aggregation.
These results indicate that Abel 576 will evolve into a single massive system over the course of hundreds of millions of years.
We propose a method for modeling epidemic spread using synthesized populations generated from massive multiplayer online games (MMOGs).
We use demographic and mobility data collected from the MMOG "Hero City," which has been continuously operating since 2003 and has over one million registered players worldwide.
The persistent world of the game is divided into multiple areas, which are interconnected through the movement between players.
Each region contains a large number of independent households, each of which can include hundreds of characters.

Our model uses this household-level information, along with the contact rates between individuals inferred from in-game observations of movement, to simulate disease spread at both regional and global levels.

We compared our results with an epidemiological model based on real census data and found that there is a good consistency between the two when we appropriately scale down the size of the simulated population.

This indicates that large-scale virtual worlds, such as massively multiplayer online games (MMOGs), can be used to study epidemics without the need to obtain sensitive personal health records or detailed demographic data.
We study the shelling type order on the regular cell complex, which is defined by ordering its cells in such a way that each new face is attached to exactly one old face on its boundary.
We demonstrate how these are used to construct acyclic pairings for the Salvetti complex associated with any finite Coxeter group W.

This gives a combinatorial proof showing that the Poincaré polynomial of the complex satisfies \( P(t) = (1 - t)(1 + \sum_{w \in W} t^{l(w)}) \), where \( l \) represents the length function on \( W \).
