We studied the dynamics and emission properties of accretion flows dominated by convection (ADAFs), where the viscosity is caused by magnetic reconnection between magnetic field lines anchored to black holes with different rotation rates.

We found that, for reasonable parameter values, this advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF) can produce luminosities as high as those observed in quasars, without violating any observational constraints regarding the mass accretion rate or temperature at its large radius.
The main reason our model performs well is that it naturally generates an outflow wind component, whose kinetic energy flux is much greater than its thermal energy flux.
This wind carries away most of the angular momentum, causing the flow near the black hole's event horizon to become almost Keplerian.
In addition, we also indicate that this wind provides enough pressure support to resist gravity, thereby preventing the gas density from becoming too low in that area.
Our results indicate that the winds produced by the magnetized self-accumulating plasmas may be the reason driving the powerful radio jets in active galactic nuclei.

This book is prepared for students completing their first-year course in control theory, aiming to help them gain a deeper understanding of discrete-time systems, digital controllers, and computer-based control technologies.

The text covers topics such as state space representation, stability analysis, optimal control design, robustness issues, model predictive control (MPC), and fuzzy logic-based control, with a focus on practical applications.
It also includes several examples that illustrate the key concepts discussed in each chapter.
This textbook comprehensively covers the fundamental principles of various aspects of modern control engineering.
In addition to the theoretical foundation, it also provides a large number of numerical examples to illustrate the important concepts introduced in this process.
The exercises at the end of each chapter help readers consolidate their understanding of the content discussed earlier.
Finally, there are two appendices that contain additional information useful for further study or research work.
This book can be used by graduate students pursuing advanced courses in control theory, as well as researchers working in the field.

The origin of this effect lies in the transverse force caused by spin-orbit interaction, which causes the trajectory of the moving particles to deviate, resulting in a finite spin polarization at the edges.
In recent years, several theoretical studies have been dedicated to understanding various aspects of the spin Hall effect.

We present observations of a set of distant galaxies in the mid-infrared to far-infrared (5.8 - 160 microns) from the Spitzer Space Telescope. These galaxies were selected based on their rest-frame ultraviolet luminosity density at 1600 Å, and we compare these flux densities with model predictions that include dust extinction.

We found that the observed infrared radiation is usually higher than the levels expected based solely on the slope of the ultraviolet continuous spectrum; if there is a significant amount of cold dust associated with star formation activity in these systems, then this excess radiation can be explained.

The results indicate that the vast majority of the energy produced by young stars may not escape into interstellar space, but is instead reprocessed by interstellar dust particles and then re-emitted in the form of infrared radiation.

We studied the impact of masking parts of the sky on the temperature fluctuations of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation using simulated datasets. We found that it is very important to consider the influence of masked pixels when estimating the angular power spectrum (APS) on large angular scales, especially for low multipoles where l < 20.
We also found that if there is a significant correlation between the masked and unmasked areas, the APS estimated using the standard method based on spherical harmonics decomposition may be biased.
In this work, we propose an improved method that takes these influences into account.
The new method has been applied to estimate the APS of the WMAP three-year dataset, provided that point sources with detected intensities exceeding 5 mJy beam⁻¹ have been removed.

We report observations of four active galactic nuclei (AGNs) classified as "obscured AGNs" with a column density greater than 10^24 cm^-2, detected by the Swift/BAT survey, using Suzaku.
We found that all these sources exhibit strong iron K line emission, and their line widths are broader than the expected thermal width at kT = 100 keV.
The observed spectral line features can be well reproduced by a relativistic disk reflection model that includes the effects of Compton scattering.
These results indicate that, in addition to the standard thin accretion disk surrounding supermassive black holes, there is an additional component to the X-ray continuous spectrum.
In addition, we found that among the four objects, three had iron abundances higher than 1.5 times the solar value.
This indicates that the central engines of these obscured active galactic nuclei may be buried under a thick disk of dust.
Finally, we discuss the possible origins of this new type of buried supermassive black hole based on our observational results.

We report the discovery of an unexpected annular dark matter structure in the galaxy cluster CL0024+17, which is located approximately 3 billion light-years away and has been extensively studied using various observational techniques, including gravitational lensing.

The mass distribution inferred from strong gravitational lensing shows that there are two massive subclusters separated by 1 Mpc (3 arc minutes), with a total mass of 2 x 10^15 h^-1M_sun within a radius of 0.5 h^-1 Mpc from the center.
We found that this double clustering system can be well described as a dual amalgamation model, where each component consists of three parts: a main halo and two smaller halos surrounding it.

In addition to these six galaxy clusters, we also discovered another small galaxy cluster near the center of the merging system, which coincides with the peak of X-ray emissions observed by the Chandra satellite.
We analyzed the distribution and properties of open star clusters in the Galactic anti-center region, using data from the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS).
We have compiled a list of all open star clusters within 8 kpc of the Sun that have an angular diameter greater than 1 arcminute.
The total is approximately 1000.
The sample includes most of the known open star clusters in this region of the galaxy.

By fitting the theoretical stellar evolution tracks to the observed color-magnitude diagrams of each star cluster, we constructed a map showing their spatial distribution and luminosity distribution using the resulting luminosity distances.

Our results show that open clusters consist of two distinct populations: one group is located between 4,000 to 6,000 parsecs and is less than 3 billion years old; the other group is located beyond 7,000 parsecs and is more than 5 billion years old.
Based on a single stellar population model of different convective theories, we present new results regarding the ages, metallicities, and α-element abundances of Galactic Globular Clusters (GGCs).

We found that the ages obtained using the classical mixing length theory are systematically younger than those derived from assuming the Red Giant Branch phase as either fully convective or semi-convective.
The difference in age between these two groups is at most about 500 million years.

For some metal-rich GGCs (Globular Galactic Clusters), we also found that the ages inferred from the classical mixing length theory can be as young as 1 billion years, whereas other methods suggest that the ages of these clusters should exceed 12 billion years.
This difference may be due to the classic mixing length theory's inability to accurately reproduce the color-magnitude diagrams observed in these metal-rich Galactic globular clusters.
Our results show that there is no significant correlation between the age of the star clusters and their metallicity.
These findings suggest that the formation history of GGCs may not be dominated by a single collapse, but rather by a process of hierarchical assembly.
We provided an overview of vortex theory in sparse atomic gases trapped at low temperatures.
We discussed how these systems can be described using macroscopic wave functions and demonstrated how they are governed by the nonlinear Schrödinger equation with an external potential.
The solutions to this equation have been extensively studied over many years, and we review some properties related to vortex formation.

Specifically, we consider the steady states corresponding to configurations of condensates without rotation (without vortices), as well as the rotating states that carry quantized angular momentum through phase singularities known as vortices.
Finally, we briefly describe the latest experiments on the generation of vortices in cold atom clouds.
Vortices naturally appear in superfluids, such as liquid helium or dilute atomic gases.
They are quantized angular momenta, which play an important role in various physical phenomena, including turbulence and quantum transport processes.
Here, we provide an introduction to the theoretical description of vortices in trapped atomic gases.
We present deep imaging data of the nearby dwarf spheroidal galaxy Draco (dSph) obtained using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT).
The new observations are used to study the structures and stellar populations in the system.
We found that the surface brightness profile can be well described by an exponential function over most of its range, but there is evidence of a breakpoint appearing at about a 30 arcsecond radius.

Using a color-brightness diagram, we show that there are two different components within the Dragon Galaxy; one has been stripped away, while the other appears to remain intact.

Finally, using our photometric catalog, we measured the velocity dispersion along the line of sight as a function of the projected distance from the center of Hercules.
Our measurement results indicate that the central region of Orion shows higher values compared to the values measured in the outer regions.
The concept of crystal defects has been developed by the Russian school since the 1930s.
The main point is that any crystal can be regarded as an elastic continuum, with its ideal structure having some local deviations, which are referred to as defects.
In this work, we briefly review the historical development of solid defect theory.
We also discussed the modern concepts of point defects (dislocations), line defects (twists), and continuous defects.
Finally, we provide examples of how these ideas are applied to different physical systems, such as liquid crystals or magnetic materials.
Defects play an important role in many fields of physics, from solid-state physics to condensed matter physics, and even biology.
They naturally occur in phase transitions between ordered states, such as phase transitions that occur at the melting point or critical temperature.
For example, they may cause plastic deformation of metal or glass materials.
On the other hand, defects are significantly responsible for the macroscopic properties of solids, such as electrical conductivity or magnetization.
We propose an algorithm that systematically scans all possible 7-colorings of a grid and reports its performance in terms of runtime and memory consumption.
The algorithm is based on a simple backtracking scheme, combined with some heuristic methods to prune parts of the search space.
We have implemented this algorithm using Java 1.6 and tested it on multiple instances, ranging from small grids to large grids containing over one million nodes.
For each instance, we provide detailed information about how much time our program spent on the coloring process and how many colors were used.
In addition, we also present a comparison of these results with those obtained from other algorithms proposed in recent literature.

Introduction  
A graph G = (V, E) consists of two sets V and E, where V represents the set of vertices or nodes, and E represents the set of edges between pairs of nodes.
The edge e = (u, v) connects node u ∈ V and node v ∈ V.
If such a connection does not exist, then e is not included in E. A path P is defined as a sequence of different nodes v1, v2, …, vn, such that for i = 2, 3, …, n, there is an edge vi−1vi ∈ E.
A cycle C is defined as a path whose starting node and ending node are the same.

A connected component is a subgraph H of graph G that has the property that any pair of nodes within H can be connected by a path within H, but cannot be connected by a path outside of H. A clique K is a complete subgraph of graph G; that is, every pair of nodes in K is adjacent to each other.
A k-clique is a clique composed of exactly k nodes.
A vertex cover \( S \) is a subset of \( V \) such that every edge in \( G \) has at least one endpoint in \( S \).
A dominating set D is a subset of V.

We study the SLE (Schramm-Loewner evolution) process as the scaling limit of interfaces between different phases in the two-dimensional Ising model, which has nearest-neighbor interactions on arbitrary planar graphs, as well as its extensions to higher dimensions.

We indicate that if the underlying lattice has no loops or multiple edges, the interface is described by chordal Schramm–Löwner evolution; otherwise, it is described by radial Schramm–Löwner evolution.
The result is obtained using techniques from conformal field theory.
Specifically, we utilize the fact that the partition functions of these models can be represented as correlation functions of primary fields in certain rational conformal field theories.
This enables us to obtain explicit formulas for the probability distribution functions of various geometric quantities related to the interface, such as their winding numbers around vertices, etc.

Introduction  
The Schramm-Loewner Evolution (SLE) process was proposed by Schramm [Sch00], who demonstrated that these processes provide a natural description of the scaling limit of interfaces in statistical mechanics systems at criticality.
These processes have been extensively studied both theoretically and numerically since then.

A comprehensive review of this topic can be found in [Smi01, Sta03, Joh10].

In this work, we regard the SLE process as the two-dimensional scaling limit that separates different phases in the following category model: let \( G = (V, E) \) be any finite connected planar graph without self-loops or multiple edges.

We presented the results of X-ray studies on the supernova remnant (SNR) G299.2-2.9, based on data from the Chandra and XMM-Newton observatories.
The supernova remnant (SNR) is located in the constellation Carina and is approximately 5,000 parsecs away, which corresponds to an angular size of about 30 arcminutes.
We found that the spectrum of the object can be described by two thermal components, with temperatures of T1 = 7 × 10^6 K and T2 = 2 × 10^6 K, respectively.
In addition, we detected non-thermal radiation above 10 keV. Using these parameters, we estimate the age of this supernova remnant to be t = 4000 years.
The value aligns very well with the characteristic time for the shell to expand into the surrounding medium.
Based on our analysis, we conclude that the observed morphology of supernova remnants is consistent with the model of a spherical explosion expanding into a uniform interstellar medium.
This study presents the design and kinematic analysis of Parallel Kinematic Machine Tools (PKMTs) using dynamic-static performance criteria.
The proposed method takes into account the dynamic behavior of PKMT during the operational process, which has been overlooked in previous research related to PKMT.
In addition to the static stiffness matrix, the inertial characteristics were also considered to evaluate the overall dynamic response of the PKMTs.
A new method based on the concept of virtual joints has been developed to calculate the mass distribution of each leg of the considered PKMT (Pneumatic Kinematic Manipulator Tool).
The information can be used as an input dataset for further dynamic analysis, such as modal or harmonic vibration analysis.
Finally, using the proposed method, two different PKMTs were designed and analyzed, each joint having three degrees of freedom.
The study found that the first PKMT has better dynamic characteristics compared to its corresponding model, as it has a lower natural frequency and a higher damping ratio.
The geochemical behavior of uranium (U) and thorium (Th) as radioactive elements is discussed, involving their impact on the origin and evolution of the Earth's crust as well as biological evolution.
The chemical properties of these two elements are similar; however, they have different physical characteristics, which will affect their geological behavior.
The atomic number of uranium is 92, and its half-life is 4.5 billion years, while the atomic number of thorium is 90, and its half-life is 1.4 billion years.
These two elements naturally exist in the earth's crust, but their concentration varies depending on the type of rock.
They can be found in igneous rocks, such as granite or basalt, where they form minerals like uranium ore or thorium ore.

These minerals may also contain other trace metals such as lead, silver, gold, copper, zinc, arsenic, selenium, molybdenum, cadmium, mercury, bismuth, antimony, tellurium, cobalt, nickel, manganese, iron, vanadium, chromium, tungsten, titanium, zirconium, niobium, tantalum, hafnium, rhenium, osmium, iridium, platinum, palladium, rhodium, ruthenium, and iridium.
Uranium and thorium also exist in sedimentary rocks, such as sandstone, shale, limestone, dolomite, gypsum, anhydrite, salt layers, and evaporites.
Sedimentary rocks are formed through the weathering process during water erosion.

The response prediction of structural systems under seismic action is very important for the design and construction of buildings in earthquake-prone areas, especially for high-rise building structures.
In this study, an artificial neural network (ANN) model was developed using data obtained from nonlinear dynamic analysis of reinforced concrete frame structures subjected to seismic records.
The ANN model consists of three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with 10 neurons, and an output layer that represents the maximum interlayer displacement ratio.

We presented the results of our research on super star clusters (SSCs) and found that super star clusters can be categorized into two types: one type has a single mode, while the other type has a dual-mode density distribution solution.

Supermassive star clusters (SMCs), also known as young globular clusters (YGCs), open clusters (OCs), and compact elliptical galaxies (CEGs), have been observed in many galactic systems, ranging from dwarf irregular galaxies to giant elliptical galaxies.

IMC seems to represent a transitional stage between open star clusters and young galaxy clusters (YGCs).

We analyze the temperature dependence of the thermally stimulated luminescence (TSL) emission curve using a non-stationary electron-phonon relaxation theory, which does not assume that the system is close to equilibrium at any moment during its evolution.

The results are compared with those obtained by other methods, such as photoluminescence excitation spectroscopy or Raman scattering.

The ultimate fate of the universe is one of the most important issues in modern physics and cosmology, but it is difficult to answer this question because quantum mechanics (QM) cannot be directly applied to macroscopic systems, such as the entire universe.
In this lecture, I will introduce a method that allows us to use quantum mechanics to study the evolution of the universe at all scales, by applying it only to small subsystems within the universe.
This method can also be used to calculate the probability distribution of the universe at the end of its existence.
The results are consistent with current observations and provide new insights into how the universe might ultimately end.

We also indicate that if the universe does indeed collapse, then it must occur within 10^(10^28) years after the Big Bang.
Finally, we discuss the potential impacts of these results on the future of humanity.

We studied the dynamic behavior of silver atoms deposited on gold (100) through molecular dynamics simulations, focusing on how this behavior is influenced by changes in substrate temperature and coverage, which causes the average number of nearest neighbors for each atom to vary from 1 to 4.
We found that, for low coverage, the system behaves as if it is made up of isolated particles that do not interact with each other.
However, at higher coverage, we observed collective effects that led to the formation of ordered structures.
The results indicate that these structures can be divided into two categories based on whether they are made up of a single layer or multiple layers of silver atoms.

We studied the fractional charge and statistical properties of fundamental excitations in quantum spin systems with frustration, using exact diagonalization techniques to investigate small clusters of up to 12 lattice sites.
We found that the ground state always has an energy gap and is non-degenerate.
The primary excitation is a fractional charge fermion or boson, depending on whether the system is antiferromagnetic (AF) or ferromagnetic (F).
In the case of the spin liquid (AF), we also observe neutral fermionic excitation states, which do not carry charge but possess nontrivial weaving characteristics.
These results can be understood by mapping our model to an effective lattice gauge theory, where the elementary excitations correspond to particles carrying flux quantization.
Our work provides a clear example of how fractional charges naturally emerge as topological defects in strongly correlated electronic materials.

This study focuses on investigating the wave dynamics of photons through position eigenvectors, which are introduced as solutions to the Schrödinger equation for photons with an arbitrary energy spectrum.
The concept of positional eigenvectors allows us to describe the state of a single photon through its position probability density distribution function (PDF).
It also enables us to introduce the concept of quantum trajectories, describing the evolution of this probability density function over time.
In particular, we demonstrate that quantum trajectories corresponding to different initial states can be obtained from one another through unitary transformations.
We demonstrate how these results can be used to analyze various phenomena related to the propagation of light in dispersive media.
Finally, we discussed the possible applications of our method in describing the non-classical effects associated with the emission of entangled photon pairs.

We propose a network self-organization method based on multi-agent systems (MAS).
The proposed method is applied to two different types of networks: one is a mobile node network, and the other is a static node network, both of which use IEEE 802.11b as the communication protocol.
In this work, we use agents that can move between adjacent nodes, allowing them to gather state information from each node.
This information can be used by other agents to make decisions, such as moving to a new location or changing transmission power levels.
We have implemented our proposal in the NS-2 simulator and compared it with three well-known algorithms: OLSR, AODV, and DSR.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is the largest biomedical research funding agency in the United States, but it also supports non-biomedical research through its external funding programs.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) funds thousands of scientists at hundreds of institutions across the country to conduct basic scientific research that may have significant applications beyond medicine.

This study examines how researchers utilize their NIH funding for non-biomedical projects by analyzing data collected from interviews conducted with researchers funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH). These interviews are part of an ongoing long-term investigation.
We found that many of these scientists primarily or completely use their NIH funding for research activities unrelated to biomedical research, such as teaching, administration, and service work.
However, we also found that some scientists who receive NIH support for non-biomedical related research still spend most of their time engaged in biomedical-related research.

This trend can be interpreted as the majority of massive galaxies having already formed stars before z~3, which is why they became redder than low-mass galaxies thereafter; thus, at high redshift, massive galaxies dominate the red sequence population.

We analyzed the transition between the first star and the second star, which are formed from the gravitational collapse of primordial gas clouds with masses ranging from \(10^4 M_\odot\) to \(10^6 M_\odot\).
We demonstrate that at redshift z < 20, the formation rate of the second star is suppressed due to the influence of light heating effects on the intergalactic medium (IGM).
The suppression factor increases as the redshift decreases, because the temperature of the cosmic medium rises faster than its density.

Unfortunately, many people who have not received scientific training do not think like physicists; they often make certain mistakes that can frequently lead them astray.

If you ask others why two objects do not fall together, she might respond that they are connected by a rope, and therefore their weights offset each other.

We consider the problem of optimal investment in the financial market, where the investor's wealth has no upper limit, but their utility function exhibits decreasing absolute risk aversion (DARA).

In this presentation, I will discuss some recent results related to lattice models, which provide an alternative approach to studying these theories.

We present numerical simulation results to study the magnetohydrostatic equilibrium of solar prominences embedded in non-potential, shear, and twisted coronal fields.

The model is based on the numerical solution of the Grad-Shafranov equation, and the boundary conditions at both ends of the computational domain are derived from the approximate analytical solution to this problem.
We found that the resulting equilibrium state exhibits features similar to the shapes observed in images of white light coronagraphs.
Specifically, we demonstrate how the shape of the coronal prominence changes when its position varies relative to the magnetic flux distribution of the underlying photosphere.

We study the problem of finding a set of optimal points on the unit circle that are equidistant from each other with the minimum angular separation, which is known as a Costas array or Costas configuration.
We demonstrate how this problem can be formulated as a convex optimization problem with linear constraints, defined in the space of probability measures supported on the unit circle.
This formula allows us to efficiently solve it using the tools of convex analysis.
In particular, we provide a polynomial-time algorithm that can compute approximate solutions within any desired level of accuracy.
The proposed method is based on the combination of the Frank-Wolfe (FW) algorithm and the Sinkhorn-Knopp scaling technique.
Finally, numerical experiments indicate that our method is more efficient compared to existing methods.
Keywords: convex optimization; probability measure; Frank Wolfe algorithm; scaling techniques; unit circle; Costas array; Costas configuration.

The Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) is one of the most famous problems in combinatorial optimization. It requires finding the optimal path that visits all vertices in a given graph while visiting each edge only once.

We demonstrated how to optimally solve the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) for these graphs using dynamic programming.

From this work, we studied the throughput capacity region of multi-hop wireless networks with multiple transmitters and one receiver (MISO-MHWN).
We first state that the MISO-MHWN corresponds to an interference channel in which each transmitter has only one antenna but can communicate simultaneously with all receivers in the network.

Then, by using the concept of degrees of freedom (DoF), which characterizes how many parallel data streams can be supported under high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions, we derive the outer boundary of the DoF region for MISO-MHWNS.

The proposed IA scheme leverages spatial reuse gain and multi-user diversity gain.

We study how the galactic disk is distorted under the tidal forces exerted by dark matter halos and interstellar gas filaments, using high-resolution cosmological simulations that include radiative cooling and star formation.
We found that the majority (over 80%) of the simulated galaxies have significant distortions at redshift z = 0.
The degree of distortion increases with the decrease in galaxy mass, but for massive galaxies, it is independent of redshift.
The distorted amplitude is usually less than 10 milli-arcseconds, which is in good agreement with the observations.
Our results indicate that the majority of the observed warping can be explained by external gravitational torques acting on the galaxy disk.
This means that there may not be any intrinsic mechanisms within the galaxy disk that cause distortion.
In addition, we indicate that the presence or absence of active galactic nuclei (AGN) does not significantly affect the distorted shape or intensity.
Finally, we demonstrated that our model predicts the correlation between the direction of warping and the angular momentum vector of the host halo.
We propose a model that describes the spontaneous formation of neuronal clusters through unsupervised Hebbian learning rules and synaptic inhibition.
The network consists of N neurons, which are interconnected by excitatory connections. The strength of these connections depends on their firing rates and varies according to a decay function.
We demonstrate how this mechanism leads to the emergence of stable states with different average activity levels and numbers of synchronized clusters.

Specifically, we found that there is a critical value of connection probability; beyond this value, the system undergoes a phase transition and enters a state where all neurons synchronize and discharge at a high frequency.
This state corresponds to the paroxysmal epilepsy observed in experiments.
In addition, we studied the impact of external stimuli on the dynamics of our network.
By applying short electrical pulses to specific groups of neurons, we can induce transitions between different dynamic states.
Finally, we discuss the potential applications of these results in neurobiology.

We present the results of an analysis aimed at determining whether a physical veto mechanism can be incorporated as part of a process to reduce false alarms when searching for gravitational waves (GW) from binary black hole mergers and other astrophysical sources.
We used data collected from the LIGO detector during the fifth scientific run, which took place from September 2005 to January 2007.
The search process is based on matched filtering, using template waveforms generated by post-Newton expansion, expanded to third-order post-Newton (3PN).

In addition to applying standard cuts based on signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), we also applied two different types of physical vetoes: 1) vetoing events with SNR exceeding certain thresholds that occur simultaneously at multiple detector locations; 2) vetoing events that show evidence of excess power above background noise levels in the frequency bands below 100 Hz or above 1000 Hz.
In each type of veto power, we define a set of parameters to control its effectiveness.
Using these parameters, we conducted a Monte Carlo simulation to study to what extent the veto measures reject simulated signals injected into real detector data.
Our main findings indicate that these two physical veto mechanisms significantly enhance our ability to detect gravitational wave signals while maintaining a low false positive rate.

VSOP (Variable Stars One-Time Observation Project) is an ambitious project aimed at obtaining high-precision radial velocities for thousands of stars, with the goal of detecting exoplanets through gravitational microlensing, transit photometry, or direct imaging techniques.
This article presents the main characteristics of this new survey and the preliminary results obtained from two open star clusters.
We used the HARPS spectrograph at the La Silla Observatory to observe over 1,000 targets in the open star cluster M67 over the course of three nights.
Our observations indicate that we can achieve an accuracy better than 1 meter per second within one hour.
In addition, we present a preliminary analysis of these data, which indicates that we are able to detect binary star systems separated by less than 0.1 astronomical units.
Finally, we report the discovery of several new spectral binary star systems in our sample.
Keywords: open clusters, radial velocity survey
The evolution of large-scale structures in the future is studied using N-body simulations with different cosmological models, which include dark energy (DE) and cold dark matter (CDM).
The results indicate that in the Λ-CDM model without dark energy, the growth rate of large-scale structures rapidly decreases in the late stages due to the influence of cold dark matter.
In contrast, under the same initial conditions, but with the inclusion of dark energy (DE), the growth rate is almost constant.
This indicates that the inclusion of dark energy (DE) can significantly affect the formation of large-scale structures on a grand scale.
We also found that there are significant differences in the density distribution of star clusters formed in these two cases.
These results suggest that it may be possible to distinguish between these two scenarios by observing cluster properties, such as their mass function or X-ray brightness.
Keywords: cold dark matter; dark energy; growth factor; clustering statistics; density distribution; cosmology.
We present the results of a binary model study of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) for progenitors with a mass range of 8-40 M⊙, which is expected to produce GRB jets that can be observed on cosmic scales.
We found that these systems evolve into double degenerate binaries consisting of two white dwarfs or helium stars, and then explode as supernovae.
The explosion was caused by the merger of components triggered by the emission of gravitational waves.
In some cases, we also found that the system goes through an intermediate stage where one component collapses to form a black hole, while the other explodes in a supernova-like manner.
This situation may explain why there seems to be a gap between the masses of ordinary core-collapse supernovae and gamma-ray bursts.
Our calculations indicate that if the progenitor star cluster extends to lower masses, the total annual number of such events could be up to 10 times higher than previously estimated.

We found that the mass loss rate of these celestial bodies is very high (from 10^-6 to 10^-5 solar masses per year), and their outflow velocity ranges from 100 to 200 kilometers per second.
The observed linear features are consistent with the wind expansion shell model.
Through addition, we detected several forbidden transitions, indicating the presence of highly ionized species such as Fe +, Si ++, and S ++.
These ions may be formed through photoionization or collisional ionization processes in stellar winds.

We have proposed an analytical solution to address the bending problem of thin elastic shells with variable thickness under surface loading. This solution is applicable in cases where the shell thickness varies by several orders of magnitude over its radius, and the load distribution does not necessarily have axial symmetry.

We prove that in this case, accurate results can be obtained using only two parameters, rather than the three parameters that were previously thought to be necessary (the third parameter being the ratio between the maximum and minimum values of shell thickness).
The new formula allows us to calculate the deflection at any point on the shell surface without having to solve additional equations or perform numerical integration.
This makes our method faster than previous approaches while maintaining high accuracy.
Our method can be used to simulate the response of the Earth's crust to tectonic stress, as well as other processes such as volcanic loads and sediment deposition.
It also has applications in geophysics beyond Earth sciences, including planetary science, astrophysics, and seismology.

In order to study the deformation of the crust, we need to understand how the stress field varies in different regions of the Earth.
In particular, we are very interested in how the stress field evolves during interactions at plate boundaries (such as subduction zones and transform faults).
To this end, we use elastic theory to find solutions to problems involving the interaction between tectonic plates and the underlying mantle.
However, solving these problems analytically requires simplifying assumptions about the geometric shape of the system and the mechanical properties of the materials involved.
In studying the mechanics of plate boundaries, an important simplifying assumption is that their behavior can be treated as if they are composed of thin elastic shells.
These shells have been demonstrated to approximate more realistic plate boundary models well, as they allow for rapid calculations of the stress fields within them.
For example, Figure 1 shows a comparison between the predictions obtained using a simple spherical shell model and those generated by a finite element model for the San Andreas Fault system.
Figure 1: Comparison of predicted displacements along the San Andreas Fault calculated using the spherical shell model (blue line) and the finite element model (red dots).

We proposed a theory of anomalous diffusion, expressed through a fractional Fokker-Planck equation, and applied it to study the temporal evolution of chemical reactions occurring on real self-affine fractals, such as porous media or biological tissues.

We indicate that the rate of reactant consumption is determined by the geometry of the medium, which is represented by an effective fractal dimension D(t) that evolves over time according to a nonlinear differential equation.
The solution of this equation depends on the initial conditions and can be obtained through numerical calculation using standard methods.
In particular, we found that if the initial distribution has compact support, the system reaches equilibrium after a certain characteristic relaxation time t*.
For times greater than t*, the consumption rate becomes independent of the initial conditions and is consistent with the consumption rate predicted by classic mean field theory.
This result indicates that in complex environments, the dynamics of chemical reactions may only be described by simple models based on environmental geometric information.

Based on this work, we propose an encounter-based worm interaction model to evaluate the performance of different node features in detecting and preventing the spread of worms in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs).

We consider two types of nodes with different capabilities to detect and prevent worms: ordinary nodes, which are susceptible to worm infections but can use signature detection techniques to detect worms; and immune nodes, which have no vulnerability to worm infections but can prevent the spread of worms through isolation mechanisms.
The proposed model is used to study how these two types of nodes interact when they encounter each other during network operation.

In particular, our results indicate that: 1) Immune nodes play an important role in reducing the number of infected nodes and the total number of contacts between susceptible and infected nodes; 2) Immune nodes should be strategically deployed within mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs); 3) Immune nodes should focus not only on isolating infected nodes but also on isolating suspicious nodes; 4) Immune nodes should use both signature detection and isolation mechanisms simultaneously to achieve better performance in mitigating worm propagation; 5) Immune nodes should adopt dynamic isolation strategies instead of static ones, as static isolation may lead to unnecessary isolation of legitimate nodes.
The field of astronomical research has a vast space for discoveries, with various types of surveys being conducted across all wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum.

In this presentation, I will discuss how wide-field optical imaging surveys are used to discover new types of celestial objects in our universe, such as quasars, galaxies, galaxy clusters, supernovae, and gamma-ray bursts, as well as how these surveys are currently providing data about the dark energy that drives the acceleration of the universe.
The next generation of large-scale surveys (such as LSST) will provide a larger volume of data, enabling researchers worldwide to take advantage of this data.

This presentation will illustrate some recent results obtained using current and past survey data, including the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), Pan-STARRS1, the Dark Energy Survey (DES), and the VISTA Kilo-degree Infrared Galaxy Survey (VIKING).

We connect the concept of information-theoretic security with computational indistinguishability, and demonstrate how to utilize this relationship in practice to prove the security properties of cryptographic protocols.
We also proposed an algorithm that can convert any protocol secure against passive attackers into a protocol secure against active attackers (under certain reasonable assumptions).
The conversion retains all communication complexity metrics, such as round complexity or the number of messages exchanged between parties.
Finally, we illustrate the application of our research method in verifying the security of several well-known protocols with examples.
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in developing and analyzing the security of cryptographic protocols.
An important goal is to develop tools to show whether certain protocols are secure under different security definitions.
For example, many researchers have studied how to transform protocols that are secure only against passive attackers into protocols that are secure against active attackers.

We presented the analysis results of U Gem, which is one of the brightest and most thoroughly studied dwarf novae during outbursts.
We utilize all available photometric data to determine its ephemeris, with an accuracy better than 0.1 seconds.
The light curve shows that in the stationary state and during the outburst, each orbit has two maxima.
This fact allows us to obtain an accurate value for the mass ratio \( q = M2/M1 \) between the components in this binary star system.
Using these new values, we can estimate the absolute mass of these two stars (0.7 ± 0.05 M⊙) and their radius (3.5 ± 0.2 R⊙).

We use an effective axial model with vector interactions to study the ground state properties of two-flavor color superconducting (2SC) quark matter at finite density and temperature. This model is derived from quantum chromodynamics (QCD) under the mean field approximation.
We found the existence of a new 2SC phase, in which quarks pair to form a diquark condensate with different colors but the same flavor.
This new phase is named the Larkin-Ovchinnikov-Fulde-Ferrell (LOFF) state, as it was originally proposed to describe superfluidity in nuclear systems.
In this LOFF state, we indicate that the pairing gap parameter between quarks with opposite momenta depends on their relative angle.
When they move away from each other along the Fermi surface, the size of the energy gap rapidly decreases.
As a result, the energy band gap completely disappears near the boundary of the Brillouin zone.

We state that the Exchange-Only Optimization Potentials (OEPs) are generally not equivalent to the Kohn-Sham (KS) method, even when using exact density functionals to calculate the exchange-correlation energy.
We demonstrate this by analytically solving the anomalous exchange-correlation equations (OEPs) of two simple model systems using Gaussian-type orbitals as basis functions.
The results obtained from these two methods have significant differences.
In particular, we found that the KS method gives incorrect total energy values for these systems.
This is because the KS equation does not have solutions corresponding to all possible densities generated by the given basis set.
On the other hand, the OEP formalism always provides a unique solution for any given density matrix.
Our analysis also demonstrates how to resolve the apparent paradox that arises when attempting to apply the OEP form using only a limited number of basis functions.
The STE R E O experiment aims to search for massless neutrino oscillations in the CERN Neutrino to Gran Sasso (CNGS) beamline using two identical detectors located close to and far from the source.

The detector consists of an active target made up of three concentric cylindrical bodies, with the inner part filled with liquid scintillator, and the outer part composed of passive shielding made of lead bricks and iron plates.
The total mass used by each detector is approximately 1 ton.
The innermost cylinder contains 0.5 tons of pseudo-Coulomb mixed with PPO as a solvent and POPOP as a wavelength converter.
The second and third layers each contain 0.3 tons of mineral oil.
Each detector is equipped with 192 photomultiplier tubes arranged in eight rings surrounding its central axis.

In addition, there are four plastic scintillator planes surrounding the exterior of the first cylinder, which provide additional information about charged particles entering or leaving the effective volume.
Globular clusters are dense stellar systems that contain thousands to millions of stars and are possibly the oldest known gravitationally bound objects.
The discovery of planets around other stars raises the question of whether members of globular clusters can also have planetary systems.
In this work, we use Monte Carlo simulations to investigate how many planets can exist in globular clusters of different masses and ages.

We found that for most reasonable assumptions about planetary formation rates, almost every star should have at least one planet, except for the youngest (<10 million years) and lowest mass (<100 solar masses) star clusters.
This result is robust against the uncertainties in our knowledge of planetary formation efficiency and initial conditions, such as the number density distribution of planetary formation materials.
Our results indicate that it is possible to detect planets orbiting the members of globular clusters using current observational techniques.
Keywords: planetary systems; stellar evolution; star clusters; formation
We discussed the gauge invariance properties of the effective action obtained by integrating out the heavy degrees of freedom (such as quarks and gluons) in supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory.
We indicate that these effects are generally not invariant under local gauge transformations unless certain formal conditions are met.
These results have significant implications for constructing gauge-invariant observables in supersymmetric gauge theories.
They also provided an explanation that even if supersymmetry does not allow for any explicit breaking terms at tree level, it is still possible to construct a nontrivial superpotential.
Finally, we believe that our research results can be used to address some puzzling features observed in recent lattice simulations of N = 1 supersymmetric QCD with four flavors.
Supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory plays an important role in particle physics and string theory.
Their low-energy dynamics are described by an effective action that incorporates all quantum corrections arising from the integration over heavy fields (such as quarks or gluons).
This effective action has been widely studied in recent years, but there are still many unresolved questions regarding its precise structure.
A specific question concerns whether this action is normatively invariant.
It has already been evident for over twenty years.
If the integration is only performed over a large number of fermions, then the resulting effective action is indeed gauge-invariant.
However, there are counterexamples, when a large number of bosonic degrees of freedom are included, where the effective action does not maintain gauge invariance [2].
Recently, this issue has sparked renewed interest among people because of its relevance to understanding non-perturbative phenomena in supersymmetric gauge theories [3, 4].
In this work, we systematically use functional methods to study the properties of gauge invariance.
Our main result is that the effective action is always gauge-invariant with respect to the total derivative, as long as two conditions are satisfied.
First, the effective action must not include higher-order time derivatives acting on the background field.
Secondly, the coefficients in front of the various operators in the effective action must satisfy certain relations.
For example, they cannot explicitly rely on the coupling constant g.
If any condition is violated, the effective action will not be able to maintain its normative character.

We propose an effective method that introduces two types of potentials to maintain the total energy and linear momentum in molecular dynamics (MD) simulations: one that is used during the MD run and another that is used only when calculating the forces on particles at each time step.
The latter type of potentials are disabled after calculation so that they do not affect subsequent molecular dynamics trajectories.
We demonstrated how to implement the scheme into the existing molecular dynamics code with minimal modifications.
In addition, we demonstrate its effectiveness through several examples, including liquid argon, water clusters, and carbon nanotubes.
Our results indicate that our new approach effectively preserves energy and momentum without incurring additional computational costs compared to traditional methods.
This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation, with fund numbers 10874145 and 10934011.
Keywords: energy-momentum conservation; switching potential; molecular dynamics.
We propose the first supersymmetric extension of the isometry group of string theory, referred to as the hidden dimension (HD) group.

The HD group includes all known symmetries in string theory as subgroups, including the Poincaré symmetry in ten-dimensional spacetime, the SO(32) gauge symmetry of the heterotic string, and the E8×E8 or SO(16)×SO(16) gauge symmetry of type IIA or IIB superstrings.

We have proven that the HD group can be realized on any closed Riemann surface of genus g > 1 by constructing an explicit action for it in the space of conformal field theories associated with that surface.
This construction generalizes the results obtained previously using singularity techniques, but has several advantages in comparison.
In particular, our approach allows us to construct new string compactification models without introducing additional massless states in the tree-level spectrum.
We study the semiclassical dynamics of electrons in a magnetic field, described by the Dirac equation that includes spin-orbit coupling and Zeeman splitting.
We demonstrate that when the initial velocity of the electron is opposite to the direction of the electric field lines, the electron trajectory can be focused into a narrow beam.

This is due to the interaction between two types of motion—the conventional cyclotron and the so-called "tremor" oscillation—which leads to the emergence of a beating pattern on top of the classical circular orbit.
The generation of motion of the latter type is due to the relativistic properties of particles, which stem from the spin splitting of the energy bands.
Our results provide a new perspective on the physics behind phenomena such as the quantum Hall effect or the integer quantum Hall effect under high Landau levels.

We proposed an effective numerical method to solve the nonlinear dynamical problem of semiconductor microcavity lasers with arbitrary pump characteristics and cavity loss, based on the combination of two different truncation schemes.

The first method is used to reduce the number of equations by eliminating those that are unrelated at any given moment; this allows us to obtain accurate results even when only a few modes make a significant contribution to the total emission spectrum.
The second method is used to eliminate the rapid oscillating terms that arise due to the presence of multiple longitudinal modes within each transverse mode family.
We demonstrate how these two techniques can be combined into a single algorithm, which we call "Dynamic Control Truncation" (DCT).
Finally, we demonstrated the accuracy and efficiency of our method by comparing it with other existing methods.
Specifically, we consider three different types of pumping characteristics: constant pumping, periodic pumping, and stochastic pulse pumping.

We proved that the set of all univariate polynomials with integer coefficients can be uniquely represented as a sum of squares of rational functions, and we provided an explicit algorithm to compute such representations.
We also demonstrated how to extend this result to multivariate polynomials over finite fields.
The problem of whether a given polynomial is a sum of squares (SOS) has been extensively studied since Hilbert's work on quadratic forms in the 19th century.
Especially, Artin proved that every non-negative integer can be represented as the sum of the squares of four integers; see [1].
This theorem means that any positive integer n can be expressed as the sum of at most 4 integer squares.
However, each number can be represented as the sum of the squares of two or three integers in infinitely many ways.
For example, 1 = 3 + √3, but it can also be written as 1 = 2 - √3.
When the restrictions are limited to certain classes of polynomials, the uniqueness problem becomes more interesting.
This indicates that if \( f \in Z[x] \) is a unit leading coefficient polynomial and its Galois group \( G(f) \) is solvable, then \( f \) can be uniquely expressed as SOS [2].
On the other hand, if \( G(f) \) contains an unsolvable subgroup, then \( f \) may have multiple distinct SOS representations.

This article presents new data on the paleogeography and geodynamics of the Russian Arctic during the Late Quaternary, based on the author's field research results conducted over the past decade.
The research area is located between the Leina River to the west and the Colima River to the east (Figure 1).
It includes the northern part of Yakutia, the southern part of Chukotka Autonomous Okrug, and the western part of Magadan Oblast.
In the region, the author studied over 100 sites with loess-like sediments that were accumulated during the last glacial period.
These are mainly sandy silt containing gravel particles with a diameter of up to 5 millimeters; they include many shells of mollusks, bones of terrestrial mammals, and other biological remains.
Based on these materials, we have reconstructed the history of climate fluctuations in the study area from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to the present.

We present new photometric and spectroscopic observations of two stars, HD 122563 (=HR 5171A) and BD+17°3248, which are suspected to be members of the proposed intermediate-age population of helium-rich giants in the globular cluster Omega Centauri.

We found that the climate parameters of these two stars are very similar to those of other candidate helium-rich giants discovered in previous studies in the Large Magellanic Cloud (Omega Cen): effective temperature T_eff = 8200 K; surface gravity log g = 3.8; [Fe/H] = -1.0 dex.
The observed spectrum did not show evidence of He II spectral lines at 4686 Å or 5412 Å, but it did exhibit strong Balmer line emission, with equivalent widths ranging from -40 to -50 milliangstroms.
These results indicate that these stars may actually not belong to the proposed category of objects.
However, based solely on our current dataset, we cannot rule out the possibility that they are indeed helium-rich giants.

We present the first results of the clustering measurements of bright red galaxies (LRGs) in the redshift range of 0.5 < z < 0.8, obtained using the AAOmega multi-object spectrograph at the Anglo-Australian Observatory.
We use data from the 2dF-SDSS LRG and QSO surveys to measure the projected correlation function wp(rp).
The observed clustering amplitude is consistent with the linear theory predictions based on the current cosmological model.
This result provides an important test of these models within this redshift range, as there are almost no other constraints available in that range.
Additionally, we found evidence suggesting that, between our two samples, the deviation parameter of the Milky Way evolved over a separation of approximately 0.2 billion years.
These results will be detailed elsewhere.
Keywords: luminous red galaxies; aggregation; deviation evolution; cosmology.

1. Introduction  
Recent studies have shown that luminous red galaxies (hereinafter referred to as LRGs), selected by their optical color or near-infrared photometry, are powerful tools for probing large-scale structures at high redshifts (for example, Eisenstein et al., 2001; Wake et al., 2006; Padmanabhan et al., 2007; Blake et al., 2008; Ross et al., 2008).
Their high brightness means that they can be efficiently detected even at relatively low redshifts, and their reddish color makes them easy to identify spectroscopically.
They also tend to be located within massive dark matter halos, which evolve slowly over cosmic time, making them useful probes of the underlying mass distribution.

Therefore, they provide a unique opportunity to study the growth of structure and the nature of dark energy that drives its accelerated expansion (see, for example, the review by Percival and White in 2009).

Here, we report for the first time the measurement of the spatial clustering properties of Luminous Red Galaxies (LRGs) in the redshift range of 0 < z < 0.8, using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) (York et al. 2000) and the Two-Degree Field Galaxy Redshift Survey (2dFGRS) (Colless et al.).

clean_wm_text: This study aims to assess whether virtual ultrasound (US) puncture pathways can improve the effectiveness of percutaneous nephrolithotomy in patients with complex anatomical structures and difficult visualization through fluoroscopic imaging of the renal pelvis.
A total of 50 continuous patients underwent ultrasound-guided percutaneous nephrolithotripsy under real-time imaging guidance with an indoor C-arm system.
The surgery is performed under general anesthesia or sedative anesthesia.
A preoperative CT scan was performed without the injection of a contrast agent for the veins.
Using OsiriX MD software, two urologists outlined the contours of the kidneys and identified all visible renal calyces.
Subsequently, they projected their findings onto real-time fluoroscopic images during the surgery.
They were asked to perform punctures in each renal calyx that could be observed through fluorescent imaging.
After successful puncture, an attempt is made to remove the stones through the sheath tube inserted by the needle.
The definition of a successful puncture is that it reaches at least one kidney pelvis.
The overall success rate is 88%.
No complications related to the use of American puncture pathway imaging have occurred.
This technology may help urologists achieve safe and effective percutaneous renal puncture, even when only a few renal pelvises are clearly visible under fluoroscopy.

The next-to-minimal supersymmetric standard model (nMSSM) is an extension of the minimal supersymmetric standard model, which includes additional Higgs doublets and singlet fields, as well as new vector-like quarks and leptons.
The phenomenological consequences of this model have been studied in detail using advanced tools to achieve precise calculations at both low and high energy scales.
Specifically, we study the impact on dark matter searches, electroweak observables, flavor physics constraints, LHC features, and direct detection experiments.
We found that the nMSSM can accommodate all current experimental data with minimal fine-tuning while providing viable candidate particles for cold dark matter.
This presentation will showcase our results.
It was presented by Jens Hjorth-Jensen at the EPS-HEP 2013 conference held in Vienna, Austria, from July 24 to 29, 2013.

We consider the linearization problems of the Painlevé equations PIII, PV, and PVI, focusing on their Lax pairs.
We prove that these problems are equivalent to certain simplified forms of the three-wave resonance system.

The results obtained here can be seen as an extension of the research by Zakharov and others, who studied the simplification of the two-wave resonance system corresponding to the Painlevé II equation.

In particular, we prove that if additional conditions are imposed on the asymptotic behavior near the origin, then the linearized PIII or PV equations do not have nontrivial solutions that exhibit exponential decay at infinity.

The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope (formerly known as GLAST) was planned to be launched in June 2008 and is capable of detecting gamma rays in the energy range from 20 MeV to 300 GeV, covering an energy range that had not been explored by previous space instruments.
The LAT instrument on the Fermi satellite consists of four identical towers, each containing 16 silicon strip trackers, surrounded by tungsten converters, with CsI(Tl) scintillators at the back.
Each detector module has a thickness of 1 centimeter and contains 12 layers of silicon strips, which are arranged at different angles relative to each other.
The design allows for the accurate measurement of the direction and energy of incident photons.
In addition, there are two calorimeter parts behind the detector module, which contain 8 CsI(Tl) planes.
These detectors provide excellent angular resolution and good energy resolution over most energy ranges.

The main objective of this work is to gain an in-depth understanding of the diffuse radiation in the Milky Way observed by the LAT detector, so that accurate modeling can be achieved when analyzing the data collected during its mission.

We study the stability characteristics of magnetized relativistic flows with spiral symmetry. These flows are described by exact solutions obtained from the coupling of the Einstein field equations and Maxwell's equations, where the electromagnetic field is either purely electric or purely magnetic along each fluid line.
We demonstrate how to construct these solutions using the Newman-Penrose formalism and discuss their physical interpretations.

Specifically, we find that there are two types of such solutions, depending on whether they contain a "generator region" where the magnetic energy density increases exponentially (thus cannot match any solutions at spatial infinity).
The latter includes all known static axially symmetric black hole electrovacuum solutions.
Finally, we present some new results regarding the existence of time-dependent solutions that describe collapsing magnetized fluids.
These solutions may have interesting applications in astrophysics.

This study explores the effects of quantum electrodynamics (QED) on the dynamics and decoherence of semiconductor-based quantum bit (qubit) systems.

The QED effect is described through the effective interaction between a qubit system and its environment, which includes vacuum fluctuations of the electromagnetic field and thermal photons at finite temperatures.
We indicate that, for typical experimental parameters, QED effects can be treated using perturbation methods.
Specifically, we have found that the spontaneous emission rate of excitons into free space modes increases with the number of electrons N participating in the quantum bit state.
This results in a faster relaxation time T1, but also leads to a stronger pure decoherence rate T2.
At realistic values of N = 10 - 100, these effects remain small compared to other relaxation sources such as phonon scattering or electron-electron interactions.

We study the resonance phenomenon as an open-loop control problem, using a nonlinear stochastic model that describes the interaction between phytoplankton (plants) and zooplankton (animals).

The SIM PlanetQuest mission is to detect, discover, and determine the three-dimensional orbits of the most promising nearby habitable planets using short-term technologies.
This article describes how SIM PlanetQuest discovers these planets by measuring the astrometric wobble as they transit in front of their parent stars.

It also discusses how SIM PlanetQuest can be used to detect other types of exoplanets, such as those with high orbital eccentricities or those that are in highly inclined orbits relative to our line of sight.
Finally, it presents some preliminary results that show the expectations we should have about learning about exoplanet systems using this new instrument.

1 Introduction

Data compression has been extensively researched in the past few decades because of its significance in various applications, such as digital storage systems, communication networks, and medical imaging, among others.
A fundamental problem of data compression is how to accurately predict the size of the compressed file given the original uncompressed data.
This issue is commonly referred to as rate distortion analysis.
As is well known, the rate-distortion function characterizes the relationship between the average codeword length and the level of distortion in any optimal coding scheme [2].
The most commonly used method for solving rate-constrained optimization problems is Lagrangian relaxation.
The constrained optimization is transformed into an unconstrained optimization by introducing additional variables known as Lagrange multipliers.

Introduction

High-velocity stars (HVSs; Brown et al., 2007a; Kenyon et al., 2008) are defined as stars that possess a spatial velocity exceeding 500 km/s relative to their local rest frame.

They may originate from tidal disruption events associated with dense remnants near the center of the galaxy (GC; Hills 1988), or from binary systems where one component is accelerated through strong interaction with another object (e.g., Yu & Tremaine 2003; Bromley et al. 2006).

In addition, recent studies suggest that some high-velocity stars (HVS) may be generated through the interaction between a single star and a supermassive black hole (SMBH) located outside the center of the galaxy (Yu & Madau 2007; Sesana et al. 2007).
However, it is important to note that there is currently no strong evidence to support this scenario.

We studied the phase diagram and critical behavior of the two-component symmetric exclusion process (TCSEP) on an infinite one-dimensional lattice, where particles can only jump when adjacent positions are empty.
We demonstrate that there is no condensation phenomenon at finite density when the system has periodic boundary conditions.
However, we find that once the TCSEP is coupled with particle storage devices at both ends, it undergoes a first-order phase transition and transforms into a condensed state.
The order parameter makes a discontinuous jump along this transition line, ultimately ending at a tricritical point.
In addition, we used the Bethe ansatz technique to accurately calculate the current-current correlation function along the transition line.
Finally, we discuss how our results can be extended to higher dimensions.

We present numerical simulations to study the formation, evolution, and collapse of tranquil cloud cores caused by dynamic compression in turbulent molecular clouds.
We found that these cloud cores were formed through shock compression at the intersection of shock waves driven by supersonic turbulence.
The mass range of the cloud core is between 0.1 M⊙ and 1 M⊙, with a typical size of about 1000 AU.

These cloud cores have relatively low internal velocities (< 2 km s^-1), but during their lifetime, they can be accelerated to 10 km s^-1 due to gravitational interactions with other dense clumps within the same cloud.
Most of them evolved in a quasi-static manner for several free-fall times before the dynamic collapse, with the time scale of the dynamic collapse ranging from one to ten free-fall times.
Our results indicate that these cloud cores may be an important source of protostellar objects in star formation regions.

Quantum auction is an extension of classical sealed-bid auctions, where bidders can submit bids in a superposition state, and the auctioneer announces the winning bid by measuring the state of the system.
Compared to traditional auctions, its main advantage lies in its ability to utilize resources more efficiently when there are many items for sale or many potential buyers.
In this work, we investigate the issue of finding the optimal strategies for sellers and buyers in a multi-item and multi-buyer auction environment.
We demonstrate how to use linear programming techniques to find the seller's optimal strategy, and we provide bounds on the number of measurements needed to determine the identity of the winner.
In the case of two buyers competing for three products, our results indicate that the seller should consistently announce one product as the winner in each round, until only one buyer remains.

Quantum mechanics has been used to develop new types of auctions, allowing sellers to better determine which items they want to sell, while buyers can also make better decisions about which items they wish to purchase.
These auctions have proven to be useful, even though not all parties involved fully trust each other.
We report on the optical investigation of individual self-assembled InAs/GaAs quantum dots (QDs) under the application of an external magnetic field along the growth direction.

When the magnetic field increases to about 1 Tesla, the emission line of the quantum dots splits into two components with opposite circular polarization, corresponding to a Zeeman splitting energy of 0.5 milli-electronvolts at 4K. We observe that this splitting linearly increases as the temperature decreases to 20 milli-Kelvin and then tends to saturate below 10 milli-Kelvin. This behavior can be explained by considering the electron-hole exchange interaction and the phonon-assisted relaxation processes between different excited states in the quantum dots.

Our results show that even in strong magnetic fields of up to 5 T, the electron spin flip time confined within the quantum dot (QD) exceeds 100 nanoseconds. The MiniBooNE experiment recently reported an excess of electron neutrino-like events observed at low energy, which may be explained by a neutral neutrino with a mass of about 1 eV and a mixing angle of sin²(2θ) ~ 0.1.

In this study, we explore how these results can be interpreted within the framework of three-flavor lepton mixing, using the latest global fit experimental data for neutrino oscillation parameters and cosmological constraints on the total mass sum of active neutrinos.

We found that if we assume the observed excess signal corresponds to actual neutrino oscillation to an inert state, rather than being caused by background systems or statistical fluctuations, then the allowed parameter space is severely constrained.

The best values suitable for the mass splitting of inactive light neutrinos are Δm32 = (0.5 - 2.3) meV and Δm2 = (0.4 - 3.6) meV, with the corresponding mixing angle ranges being θ23 = 42° - 50° and θ13 > 40°.

Using the generalized gradient approximation of density functional theory, the electronic structure, equilibrium geometry, and finite temperature properties of sodium clusters containing 39 to 55 atoms have been studied.
The results indicate that the ground state always possesses C_sv symmetry, and only the lowest energy configuration of Na_55 exhibits D_5h symmetry.
For all these clusters, we found that their structural parameters, such as bond lengths, bond angles, and dihedral angles, exhibit parity effects.
We also studied the vibrational frequencies and infrared intensities of these clusters at room temperature.
The results indicate that the calculated values are very consistent with the experimentally obtained values.
Finally, we investigate the thermodynamic stability of these clusters.
Our calculations indicate that most of them have high melting points, but some of them may be unstable for dissociation into smaller fragments.
Keywords: sodium cluster, electronic structure, vibrational frequency, infrared intensity.

We present new measurements of the mean and dispersion of the velocity dispersion-optical richness relationship (VRR) for galaxy clusters selected from red sequence galaxies using data from the Seventh Data Release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS DR7).

We use two different methods to measure the velocity of galaxy clusters: one is based on spectral observations of member galaxies, and the other estimates the photometric redshift using all galaxies within a fixed aperture centered on the brightest group galaxy (BGG) of each cluster.
The results are consistent with previous studies at low redshift, but show significant differences when compared to recent studies conducted at high redshift.
The difference between our results and those presented in earlier studies may be due to systematic effects related to measurement techniques, or it may indicate an evolution of VRR over time.
In any case, these results emphasize the necessity of further research into this relationship and other scale relationships involving galaxy clusters.
Keywords: galaxy cluster, optical richness

The conformational space of side chains in proteins can be explored using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations; however, for large systems, this method requires a significant amount of computational resources.
We developed an alternative method that utilizes normal mode analysis (NMA), which has previously been shown to provide accurate predictions of protein dynamics at a low computational cost.
For our new approach, we use NMA to calculate the free energy landscape associated with each side chain rotation angle.
The generated landscape is then used as input for a statistical mechanics model, which predicts the equilibrium distribution of rotational isomers observed in experiments.
This method was tested on two small proteins containing multiple proline residues and was able to accurately predict the relative abundance of different rotamer states.
It also accurately reproduces the experimental results obtained through nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR).
Finally, we applied this method to study the effect of mutations on the distribution of rotameric isomers of several amino acids.
Our results indicate how changes in the local environment affect the torsional preferences of these residues.
We propose a variational method for integrating magnetic field observation data into numerical models.
The method is applied to a simple model problem, considering the evolution of a single magnetic vector potential component in a two-dimensional region with periodic boundary conditions.
We use this example as a testing platform to explore how the choice of different observation operators affects the quality of the final analysis field.

In particular, we compared the results obtained by directly applying our algorithm to the state variable (vector potential) with the results obtained by first projecting it onto a set of basis functions, which were chosen to be optimized at each time step to represent the solution.
Our experiments show that both methods produced similar results, but the latter can lead to significant computational savings.

Finally, we demonstrate the practicality of our method by conducting a series of twin experiments, in which synthetic magnetometer measurements are used to update the initial conditions of the simulation.

We present new optical spectral observations and archival X-ray data of the Seyfert 1 galaxy NGC 3783, which indicate that its core activity is primarily dominated by a obscured active galactic nucleus (AGN) with a luminosity of approximately ~10^43 erg/s (2-10 keV).

The observed spectral energy distribution indicates that this source has undergone rapid changes between two distinctly different states over the past decade; in one state, its radiation is close to the Eddington limit, while in the other state, it is much dimmer, yet still very bright.
We believe that these changes are likely caused by fluctuations in the mass inflow rate of the central black hole.
This explanation is supported by our analysis of the time delays between different emission lines and their linewidths.
We especially found that during the brightest period of the source, the time lag of the Hβ emission line is several hundred days longer than that of other lines, such as He ii λ4686Å and C iv λ1549Å.
We report on the measurement-induced decoherence phenomena observed in Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC) using Ramsey interference and atom counting.

The experiment was conducted by splitting a captured Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) into two spatially separated clouds, which are allowed to evolve for different amounts of time before being recombined at a beam splitter.
We observed that as we increase the number of atoms counted at one output port of the beam splitter, the visibility of the interference fringes decreases.
This effect can be explained by considering how repeated measurements influence the phase evolution of the system.
Our results indicate that cold atom experiments can be used to study fundamental questions related to quantum mechanics.
Quantum mechanics predicts that any attempt to measure a physical quantity will disturb its value.
In this work, we experimentally studied these effects in the Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC).
To this end, we conducted Ramsey interference measurements on two spatially separated regions in the sample.
By changing the time spent on free evolution after part of the initial cloud is split, we control the relative phase that accumulates during the free evolution process.
During the recombination process, we calculate the number of atoms reaching the output ports of each beam splitter and record their arrival time distribution.
As expected, we found that when the number of detected particles increases, the visibility of the resulting interference pattern decreases.
